characters: DOWDING, IRONSIDE, BRIDGES, ISMAY, NICHOLL, WILKINSON
FROM THE WAR CABINET AND SENT TO WASHINGTON
ALMOST ALL OF THE 300,000 TROOPS AT DUNKIRK
THE DEADLY DANGER HERE IS THIS
WITHIN WEEKS OF VICTORY, CHURCHILL AND HIS PARTY WERE
WERE CARRIED HOME BY WINSTON'S CIVILIAN FLEET
VISCOUNT HALIFAX WAS SOON REMOVED BY WINSTON
BRITAIN AND ITS ALLIES WOULD DECLARE VICTORY
ROMANTIC FANTASY OF FIGHTING TO THE
SINCLAIR, COOPER, CADOGAN, ANDERSON, POUND, DOWDING,
NEVILLE CHAMBERLAIN DIED SIX MONTHS LATER
VOTED OUT OF OFFICE BY THE BRITISH PEOPLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..-is in an uproar. The PRIME MINISTER, NEVILLE CHAMBERLA (71), sits with the MAJORITY, RULING CONSERVATIVE PARTY o one side of the house... .--whilst the LEADER of the MINORITY, OPPOSITION LABOUR PARTY, CLEMENT ATTLEE (57) sits with the OPPOSITION PARTI on the other side. They face each other like two warring armies. Shouting. Accusations. Wild gesturing. Paper darts thrown. Mayhem.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTION
dialogues.text: ATTLEE rises to his feet, amid jeers and heckles, to deno CHAMBERLAIN, directly opposite him across the aisle -

dialogues.speaker: ATTLEE
dialogues.text: Mr Speaker! Mr Speaker!

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: The Honourable Leader of the Opposition, Clement Attlee!

dialogues.speaker: ATTLEE
dialogues.text: Mr Speaker--Mr Speaker--it seems I have not been clear enough. Then let me leave no doubt regarding my feelings about Mr Chamberlain's future as Prime Minister. (over boos and applause) Owing to his years of inactivity and incompetence - (cheers and boos) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - we find him personally responsible, personally responsible for leaving our nation ruinously unprepared to face the present Nazi peril. We are at war, Mr Speaker. At war. And leaving aside whether he is fit to be a leader in peace- time he has proven himself incapable of leading us in war- time. Cries of support to this - Looking down from the LORDS GALLERY is - VISCOUNT HALIFAX (59), appalled by what he is seeing. He exchanges a look the bereft CHAMBERLAIN.

dialogues.speaker: ATTLEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Therefore, in the national interest, we the Opposition, are willing to enter into a Grand Coalition--with the “ruling” Conservative Party, so-called!... An OPPOSITION MP stands and starts singing "Rule Britanni Others soon begin to join in.

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: Order! Order!

dialogues.speaker: ATTLEE
dialogues.text: ..-but not, and I stress this, never, under the leadership of Mr Chamberlain... (angle on CHAMBERLAIN) -.-who has lost the confidence of this House! A REBEL CONSERVATIVE MEMBER rises and crosses the floor t stand with the OPPOSITION MPs, betraying Chamberlain.

dialogues.speaker: ATTLEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (directly to CHAMBERLAIN) In the country’s interest man, resign! Step down! And let us find a new leader! UPROAR, and many cry “HEAR-HEAR!” and “GO!”

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: I said, ORDER! The camera passes along the CONSERVATIVE benches to find ANTHONY EDEN (43), behind him sits KINGSLEY WOOD (59).

dialogues.speaker: KINGSLEY WOOD
dialogues.text: (into EDEN's ear) Where’s Winston? On the bench beside EDEN, as if to reserve a space, is a Royal Naval Yacht Club CAP.

dialogues.speaker: EDEN
dialogues.text: Ensuring his fingerprints are not on the murder weapon. The singing of “Rule Britannia" continues over - INT. DINING ROOM/ SIR JOHN SIMON’S COUNTRY HOUSE - NIGHT NEVILLE CHAMBERLAIN addresses the other CONSERVATIVE gues gathered around a circular dining table.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Accordingly--tomorrow--I will resign as Prime Minister. GREAT FEAR in the faces of the NOBLES. CUT BETWEEN their FACES, during the following - CHAMBERLAIN (CONT’D) (suppressing emotion) As the Opposition refuse to join a government headed by me, we must select my successor. (beat) I will step down tomorrow but I wanted my own party, the gentlemen I most respect, to know first. LORD LONDONDERRY. Halifax. There’s no question! Our Foreign Secretary -

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SIMON
dialogues.text: No contest! HALIFAX

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: I appreciate your confidence but my time has yet to come. However, on whomever the task may fall, he shall be charged with the security of these islands and of our Empire, and shall be required to explore all avenues.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Including that of Diplomatic talks.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: Indeed, towards the restoration of peace in Europe.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Hear Hear!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I’m afraid there is only one candidate. Only, one man that the Opposition will accept?

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SIMON
dialogues.text: Surely not...

dialogues.speaker: CAPTION
dialogues.text: A plate of BACON & EGGS is set on a BREAKFAST TRAY. Then. glass of WHITE WINE is poured by WINSTON’s VALET, SAWYERS and set beside the plate. A glass of SCOTCH and SODA is a prepared and set beside these on the tray. For Breakfast? SAWYERS carries the TRAY through servants quarters toward the ENTRANCE HALL of the house, where -— - the TRAY passes by - WINSTON’s PRIVATE SECRETARY, JOHN EVANS (35), as he schools the NEW YOUNG SECRETARY, ELIZAB LAYTON. Evans, an immaculately-groomed rake, snobbishly thinks himself infinitely superior to the Elizabeth Layto of the world.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN EVANS
dialogues.text: (to ELIZABETH) -..and if he stretches out his hand and says, “Gimme”, you need to anticipate what he wants - black pen, red pen, paper, or “Clop”, that’s his hole punch. EVANS and LAYTON walk past - - SAWYERS-with-TRAY, as he waits for the COOK to iron a NEWSPAPER (DAILY EXPRESS)and as the SCULLERY MAIDS, over shoulder, ANXIOUSLY read the headline: “CHAMBERLAIN TO RESIGN”

dialogues.speaker: SAWYERS
dialogues.text: Don’t smudge the ink.

dialogues.speaker: MAID
dialogues.text: How selfish to resign, time like this.

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: D’you think they’11l take me to Downing Street?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not after the Spotted Dick you served last week. The COOK then sets the PAPER on the TRAY, whereupon SAWYE carries the TRAY up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EVANS and LAYTON approach a BEDROOM DOORWAY.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN EVANS
dialogues.text: ...-He mumbles, so it’s almost impossible to catch everything. And be prepared to type fast - short bursts - and double-spaced, he hates single-spaced--hates it! Good luck. EVANS knocks on the door, opens it and then pushes the no quaking ELIZABETH LAYTON inside, closing the door again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her POV of the dimly-lit room. And then, a MATCH is struc CIGAR lit. We can just make out a MAN in bed, as -— SAWYERS tugs open the CURTAINS, revealing - - WINSTON CHURCHILL (65), in BED, with the BREAKFAST TRAY his lap, in a pink silk dressing-gown (naked beneath). Hi dispatch box, piled high with telegrams, stands open by h bed . His marmalade cat, TANGO, sits at the end of the be as WINSTON reads a dispatch and dictates...

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: To the French Ambassador. Come on -— WINSTON looks up at ELIZABETH, to see if she is writing t down. She’s not - WINSTON (CONT’D) - telegram! ELIZABETH realises, to her horror, that the dictation has already begun, and she hurries to the TYPE-WRITER, which already been loaded with a sheet...She begins to type FAS in short bursts - WINSTON (CONT’D) (dictating) With German forces crossing into Holland...Holland alone...request reassurance...that French forces will now move--move at once--to protect Belgium. Stop. Read!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) “To--to the French Ambassador. With German forces crossing into Holland...Holland alone... request reassurance that -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: - immediate reassurance - ELIZABETH adjusts the typewriter’s carriage and paten and types the word “IMMEDIATE” above the previous text...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: “— immediate - reassurance - “

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: “ — that -" Go on - “- that ” SAWYERS enters, as ELIZABETH struggles to re-set the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: “— that - “ The BEDROOM TELEPHONE rings -—-

dialogues.speaker: SAWYERS
dialogues.text: French Ambassador sir -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Monsieur Ambassador! (pause) Ah. They’ve already invaded Belgium. (pause) I will convey your plea to the Prime Minister at once. Yes, the situation is still very confused. Goodbye. WINSTON hangs up. A concerned pause, and then - WINSTON (CONT’D) Holland and Belgium. ELIZABETH types this - tap,tap,tap,tap - WINSTON (CONT’D) No, no, no.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (confused) Sir?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Scrap that. New telegram.  7. In a fluster, she pulls out the old PAGE from the TYPEWRI CARRIAGE and quickly inserts a new page, as - WINSTON (CONT’D) To General Ismay... WINSTON grabs his WHISKEY and SODA, as - the PHONE rings again. SAWYERS re-appears.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dammit Sawyers! What is it now?!

dialogues.speaker: SAWYERS
dialogues.text: Your son. WINSTON, his concentration broken, goes to the PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (into Phone) Randolph, quickly - (listens) Last night they said I may be made Prime Minister today. But that was yesterday. Let’s see what Neville does today. Thank--thank you my boy. Keep buggering on! Puts down the phone. Turns to look at ELIZABETH. WINSTON (CONT’D) Now... Sips his SCOTCH. This calms him.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH LAYTON
dialogues.text: General Ismay... Moving to the end of the bed -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Ah, General Ismay. (to Sawyers) Sawyers - get rid of this will you? Winston gestures to Sawyers to move his tray away and the swings his legs - indecorously! - out of bed. ELIZABETH quickly turns her face away! WINSTON then begins to pace WINSTON (CONT’D) In the light of today’s events, the time is ripe for many preparations to be made... (beat) Are you striking those typewriter keys in a normal fashion? It’s awfully loud, I can’t think! (beat) Read it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh--To General Ismay. In the light of today’s events, the time is right for many prep -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: RIPE! Not RIGHT! God's teeth girl! I said ripe, ripe, ripe - P-P-P! The last sentence...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH LAYTON
dialogues.text: (shaken) The--the time is ripe...

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: For! FOR!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH LAYTON
dialogues.text: (her nerve broken) ..-Many...Many...many...

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: How many “many”s did you write?! One many! (sighs) “For...for MANY preparations-—- to be made...” He walks up to her and looks over her chair, and is horri to see - WINSTON (CONT’D) Single-spaced? What are you doing?! What are you doing?!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Someone set it on single-spaced and before I realised -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Then why did you persist?!

dialogues.speaker: I-
dialogues.text: As she starts to rush out -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Tell Evans to send me someone who can do it right the first time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH comes down the stairs, and stops, her face tear stained.  CLEMENTINE CHURCHILL - WINSTON’s WIFE, 55 YEARS OLD - beautiful, elegant, highly-strung, is at that moment cros the hall, with a HANDFUL of BROWN ENVELOPES. She sees ELIZABETH.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: Ah. He shouted at you. Did he shout at you?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Yes, but I....

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: He can be an awful brute.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No! I made too many mistakes.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: I think you were nervous. And he has a knack for drawing out the very worst in those trying to help him the most.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Oh it’s not him. It’s me. He’s - he’s -

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: He’s just a man, like any other. Wait here. CLEMMIE climbs the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLEMMIE enters - WINSTON (on his knees) is looking for Ta the cat under his bed.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: My Darling?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: The War Cabinet has been called. The bloody cat is under the bed again. CLEMMIE indicates that SAWYERS should go and moves around WINSTON tucking his shirt in.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: Can I tell you something that I feel you ought to know? He looks at her -  10.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve noticed a recent deterioration in your manner. You're not so kind as you used to be. You’ve become rough, sarcastic, over-bearing and rude.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Is this about the new girl?

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: If the King asks you to become Prime Minister -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: We don’t know that -

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to be disliked.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: More than I already am?

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: Darling, you may be on the brink, the brink--of having tremendous power, surpassed only by the King. With such power you really must try to be more kind and, if possible, calm. I want others to love and respect you as I do. Clemmie falls back in the bed, shortly joined by Winston- they share a moment of fondness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT of Chartwell bathed in sunshine. ELIZABETH LAYT with hat and coat now on, is attempting to make a discree escape from the house but is stopped by a MOTORCYCLE COUR with a telegram to deliver. We do not hear what is said. CLOSE-UP on the telegram turning in ELIZABETH’S hands as COURIER rides away. ELIZABETH looks back to the house, ma her decision and re-enters the lair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH climbs the stairs holding a telegram, braced to once more enter the Lion’s Den. She enters -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and finds WINSTON, CLEMMIE, JOHN EVANS, SAWYERS and a M all listening with rapt attention to a RADIO BROADCAST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “This is BBC Home Service. Here is a short news bulletin. The German army invaded Holland and Belgium early this morning, by land, and land parachutes--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: There’s a telegram.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN EVANS
dialogues.text: Sssshhh!

dialogues.speaker: BBC RADIO ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: ..."The Armies of the Low Countries are resisting. An appeal for help has been made to the Allied governments and Brussels says the Allied troops are moving to their Support...”

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It's from the Palace. All eyes turn to look at her, as if an elephant has enter the room. A silent beat in which no-one breathes.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss...?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Layton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLEMMIE hands WINSTON his watch, glasses, cigar case, mat and a sugar cube.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: You’re shaking.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: So are you! It’s true CLEMMIE is just as nervous -

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: You from excitement--I from terror. You have been wanting this your entire adult life.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: No--since the nursery. CLEMMIE laughs.  12. WINSTON (CONT’D) But do the public want me?

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: It’s your own Party to whom you’1l have to prove yourself.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I’m getting the job only because the ship is sinking. It’s not a gift, it’s revenge.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: Let them see your true qualities. Your courage...

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: ---My poor judgement.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: .-.-Your lack of vanity.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: ...-My iron will.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: (in playful rebuke) ...Your sense of humour.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Ho Ho Ho!

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: Now go.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Go?

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: Be.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Be? She touches his face tenderly -

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: Yourself.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Which self? CLEMMIE walks away. WINSTON turns to a wall on which are hung many HATS - (Royal Naval Yacht Club Cap, Admiral’s h with plume, aviator helmet with goggles, riding hat, pith helmet, French WWl helmet, fez, Homburg, top hat, etc ) a on display like HUNTING TROPHIES.  13. WINSTON (CONT’D) (to himself) Which self should I be today? WINSTON surveys the collection, then plucks the TOP HAT f its hook - WINSTON (CONT’D) One should have had power when a young man. When wits were sharp, sinews strong. Oh well. He returns to her - WINSTON (CONT’D) Lead on Macduff-- When youth departs-- may wisdom prove enough. They kiss, and she gives him a silver BOX OF MATCHES, embossed with loving message from his children. EXT/INT. PRINCES STREET/ WINSTON’S CAR - DAY WINSTON, in the back seat, (with JOHN EVANS in front) loo out the window at the human traffic - seems like he’s ina gold-fish bowl, disconnected. He watches as - MEN IN BOWL HATS and YOUNG WOMEN in SUMMER DRESSES walk to work.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN EVANS
dialogues.text: Hardly seems like there’s a war on at all. THREE DELIVERY BOYS ride by on bicycles, notice him and w excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: How odd it is.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN EVANS
dialogues.text: Sir? They stop, waiting behind a BUS.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: You know--I have never ridden a bus. Never queued for bread. I believe I can boil an egg but only because I saw it done once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON’s car approaches the Palace gates, which are open The CAR drives up to the PALACE. WINSTON gets out and he EVANS enter the PALACE -—  14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grand hall. Winston removing his hat and coat, hands his cane and glo then hat to a LIVERIED DOORMAN whilst a LIVERIED STAFF ME waits nearby.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: The only time I tried to ride the Underground was during the General Strike. Clemmie dropped me at South Kensington station. I went down-- but I got lost and came straight back up. Awful! (girding himself) Well, “Here we go”...

dialogues.speaker: EVANS
dialogues.text: Good luck sir. WINSTON strides away, following the EQUERRY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KING GEORGE VI (agitated, troubled) speaks with the ill, weak, outgoing PRIME-MINISTER NEVILLE CHAMBERLAIN. CHAMBERLAIN watches the KING.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Why not Halifax? I favour Halifax.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: I wanted Halifax. The Lords wanted Halifax. Halifax wanted Halifax.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Then--then why have I been forced to send for Churchill?

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Because he’s the only member of our party who has the support of the Opposition.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: His record is a litany of catastrophe. Gallipoli, 25,000 dead. The India Policy. Russian Civil War. The Gold Standard. The the the Abdication. And now this Norway ‘adventure’. What, eighteen hundred men?  15.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: One aircraft carrier, two cruisers, seven destroyers and a submarine.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Winston lacks judgement.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: He was right about Hitler.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Even a stopped clock is right twice a day. EQUERRY enters.

dialogues.speaker: EQUERRY
dialogues.text: First Lord of the Admiralty, Mr Winston Churchill!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Early.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Keen.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: I accept your resignation--but I want you to know--how--cruelly I think you’ve been treated.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Thank you Your Majesty. He and GEORGE shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: EQUERRY
dialogues.text: This way, my Lord. The KING waits - SIGHS deeply, until... We hear footsteps approaching. WINSTON enters.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Mr Churchill.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I believe you know why I--I I have asked you here today.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Sir, I simply can’t imagine why.  16.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: It is my duty to-to-to invite you to take up - the position of of Prime Minister of this United Kingdom. Will you form a government?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Very well. WINSTON bows, and when the KING offers his hand, WINSTON kisses it. WINSTON rises.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That was--quite easy.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Yes. They stare at each other in uneasy silence. WINSTON (CONT’D) I believe we are to meet regularly.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Once a week, I’m afraid. How are you on--on--on Mondays?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I shall endeavour to be available on Mondays.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Four o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (resolutely) I nap at 4.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Is that--permissible?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: No. But necessary. I work late.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Then perhaps lunch?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Lunch! Mondays. (WINSTON bows) Your majesty.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Prime Minister.  17. When WINSTON backs out of the room, the KING anxiously li a cigarette, and broods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON pulls up in his PRIVATE CAR, alights, (followed b EVANS) waves at the PRESS, an effortless SELF-PUBLICIST, total ease in the spotlight. Ever the showman - taps the NUMBER 10 on the famous front door with his walking stick the amusement of the PHOTOGRAPHERS -—

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Prime Minister? First order of business, sir?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: A glass of Pol Roger! He enters the building, and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - is greeted by EDEN.

dialogues.speaker: EDEN
dialogues.text: Prime Minister!

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Anthony.

dialogues.speaker: EDEN
dialogues.text: How was the K-k-king?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Anxious. Never forgiven me for supporting his brother’s marriage to Wallis Simpson. WINSTON and EDEN step into his office, with WINSTON closi the door on EVANS in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: EDEN
dialogues.text: You only have to meet him once a week.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: That's like saying you only have to have your tooth pulled once a week. EDEN takes out a pen, opens a notebook -  18.

dialogues.speaker: EDEN
dialogues.text: Composition of your War Cabinet. Who should sit on it?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Chamberlain. And the Reverend “Holy Fox" —-

dialogues.speaker: EDEN
dialogues.text: (writes) Halifax. Keeping your enemies close?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: More than that, without them the party will get rid of me. (beat) And that sheep in sheep’s clothing, Attlee. MARY, CHURCHILL’s 18 year old daughter, appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: MARY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Come on Daddy--everyone’s waiting.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Be there in a jiffy, my love. MARY exits.

dialogues.speaker: EDEN
dialogues.text: I heard that before you were asked, they offered it to Lord Halifax.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (shakes head) I doubt that. Halifax would never turn it down. He's the fourth son of an Earl. Fourth sons turn nothing down.

dialogues.speaker: EDEN
dialogues.text: I only wish the position had come your way in better times, sir. You have an enormous task ahead of you.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I hope it’s not too late. I am very much afraid it is. But we can only do our best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLEMMIE and the CHURCHILL CHILDREN wear GAS-MASKS as they shout -  19.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Hip Hip -

dialogues.speaker: HURRAY
dialogues.text: WINSTON enters - and stops, aghast, and stares at his fam

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Good lord, what a frightful sight!

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE, SARAH CHURCHILL, (26)
dialogues.text: CHURCHILL (29) and his WIFE PAMELA (pregnant), and MARY CHURCHILL (18) all pull off their GAS MASKS, grab their glasses of CHAMPAGNE, then converge on him and kiss him. He stares at them, a SMILE FORMING AT LAST, deeply touche actually. He is presented with a glass of champagne.

dialogues.speaker: CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you. PAMELA raises her glass -

dialogues.speaker: PAMELA
dialogues.text: A toast! Come on!

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Yes! Mary makes her way to sit on a cushion on the floor next Winston. She looks proudly at WINSTON -

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: My darling husband--Something you all might not know is that on the eve of our marriage I got “cold feet”--but as I’d already called off two engagements by the age of 21 I was in danger of gaining a reputation for being a ‘bolter’-- and it would’ve been poor form to call off a third! LAUGHTER. WINSTON smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: Hear hear.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Lucky for Daddy.  20.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: But the real reason for my wintry feet was because I knew, even then, that his priority would be public life. It worried a young girl greatly--this wretched thought of coming second, eternally. But so it has proven to be. And in due course (Mary takes Winstons hand) our children would also have to make their own peace with this same fact. (directly to Winston) We all did, you see, in our own ways. And now, today, we all receive our reward--proof that our small sacrifice was for a far, far greater good. I give you, your father, my beloved husband - the Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Prime Minister! They raise their GLASSES in a toast -—

dialogues.speaker: CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Here's to--(thinks) not buggering it up.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY
dialogues.text: Not buggering it up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BIG BEN starts the WESTMINSTER CHIME -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON approaches EDEN in the ancient hall and together climb the steps beneath the great gothic WINDOW.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Belgium was a ploy. They just punched through the Ardennes into France and crossed the Meuse in under 24 hours!

dialogues.speaker: EDEN
dialogues.text: No-one can cross the Meuse River in 24 hours.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Apparently the Germans can.  21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BIG BEN strikes the hour - 3 PM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the sound of the distant BELLS, WINSTON enters, with EDEN, and small knuckle-knocking on woodwork, mainly from LABOUR benches. WINSTON looks around, not actually surprised at the contemptuous reception.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (to EDEN) Contempt. Well, you have to start somewhere. In the LORDS GALLERY, above, HALIFAX enters and looks dow proceedings, and on - WINSTON, looking at his FOB-WATCH. The HUBBUB dies down and WINSTON puts on his GLASSES.

dialogues.speaker: SIR SAMUEL HOARE
dialogues.text: (whispered, to SIMON) Here we go. WINSTON reaches into his waistcoat for his TYPED SPEECH, delivers his MAIDEN SPEECH as PRIME MINISTER...

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Mr Speaker. On Friday evening last-- I received His Majesty’s commission to form a new administration... ANGLE ON: CONSERVATIVE MP’s, all looking worried. WINSTON (CONT’D) -..It was the evident wish and will of Parliament, and the Nation, that this should be conceived on the broadest possible basis, and that it should include all parties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: TYPED PAGE (with TEXT) being rapidly tugged fro TYPEWRITER CARRIAGE (to a LOUD explosive ratchet-whirr)!!

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: A War Cabinet has been convened...  22. CLOSE ON: TYPE-WRITER keys typing...”A War Cabinet has be convened” — WIDE: ELIZABETH TYPES, as WINSTON dictates - WINSTON (CONT’D) Correction - “has been formed” - ELIZABETH adjusts the PATEN, then types - “formed” above “convened” —

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: - has been formed--of five members -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: ...representing, with the Opposition parties, the unity of the Nation.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: A FRESHLY TYPED PAGE (ROUGH DRAFT) is set down the desk by ELIZABETH’s hand. The stationary bears the Pr Minister's monogram, and we see typed TEXT plus several phrases struck out (between parentheses). The CAMERA moves in on the paragraph that reads... “The three party Leaders have agreed to serve, either in the War Cabinet, or in (positions of authority*) high executive office.” (* denotes struck through phrase)

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The three party Leaders have agreed to serve, either in the War Cabinet-

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: - or in high executive - or in high executive office. office. WINSTON (CONT’D) The three fighting Services have been filled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OUTSIDE the BATHROOM DOOR - ELIZABETH LAYTON waits, with PAD and PAPER, taking down his dictation...  23.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Sawyers is she there?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Yes she is.. I mean, I am

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don’t come in! SOUNDS of him taking a BATH, the SPONGE being squeezed ov his head...She starts to move away, but is arrested by -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don’t go away!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH LAYTON
dialogues.text: No, no--I’m still here.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: “With this agreement, I now invite the House - (water sounds) - by the resolution which stands in my name, to record its approval, and to declare its confidence in the new government.” Sound of WINSTON getting out of the BATH.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Miss? I’m coming out in a state of nature! ELIZABETH LAYTON flees, as the DOOR opens and as WINSTON (naked) looks up and down the HALLWAY to see where his TY has gone.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I now invite the House by a resolution to declare its confidence in the new government. ANGLE on the CONSERVATIVE PARTY - unimpressed. KINGSLEY-WOOD advises A JUNIOR CONSERVATIVE, ERNLE HASTIN

dialogues.speaker: KINGSLEY WOOD
dialogues.text: Look to Chamberlain’s handkerchief. If he waves it at the end of Churchill's speech, we show approval, if not, keep quiet. ERNLE HASTINGS looks over at CHAMBERLAIN.  24. CHAMBERLAIN, still on the front bench but not in the PM’s chair, draws a WHITE HANDKERCHIEF out of his BREAST POCKE and folds it in his LAP. ERNLE HASTINGS nods - understanding.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: It must be remembered that we are in the preliminary stage of one of the greatest battles in history...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: A HEAVILY MARKED-UP PAGE of TYPED SPEECH (ROUGH DRAFT) much worked-over, annotated, altered - with WINSTO HAND just then adding the latest change in the margins... see his HAND write (in his tiny cursive scrawl) - and that many (arrangements*) preparations have to be made here at home.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...and that many preparations have to be made here at home. WIDE: WINSTON, alone in his OFFICE, hunkered at NIGHT, go through the speech, meticulous, obsessive, a perfectionis

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sir, I take up my task with buoyancy and hope -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The TYPEWRITER hammers typing the CLEAN (FINAL) DRAFT of the speech, on SMALLER SHEETS of PAPER, the TEXT set out like BLANK VERSE in a POEM, or in the BIBLE, each phrase spaced apart from the next - and say to the House, as I said to those who have joined the government -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: - and say to the House, as I said to those who have joined the government —

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. WINSTONS CAR, PARLIAMENT
dialogues.text: WINSTONS car is stationary in the internal courtyard at Parliament. WINSTON, in the back seat (with ELIZABETH LAY in the front, her TYPE-WRITER on her knee, typing away) dictates.  25.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: - I have nothing to offer but blood, toil--tears--and sweat. EXTREME CLOSE ON: her keys typing: “sweat!” CLOSE ON: The PAGE being tugged from the TYPEWRITER. WINSTON alights the car, and ELIZABETH passes the PAGES o the SPEECH, which he grabs, then hurries away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: ERNLE HASTINGS, unable to take his eyes off CHAMBERLAIN, waiting for the HANDKERCHIEF to be waved. ANGLE ON WINSTON: readying himself for the final assault!

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: We have before us an ordeal of the most grievous kind. We have before us many, many long months of struggle and of suffering. You ask, what is our policy? I say it is to wage war by sea, land and air, with all our might and with all the strength God can give us--to wage war against a monstrous tyranny never surpassed in the dark and lamentable catalogue of human crime. ANGLE ON: HALIFAX, in the GALLERY - he shoots a look to CHAMBERLAIN. WINSTON (CONT’D) That is our policy. You ask, what is our aim? I can answer in one word. Victory - victory at all costs, victory in spite of terror, victory however long and hard the road may be. For without victory, there is no survival. WINSTON feels he must have won them over, but his confide smile fades as he realises he stands alone. Small KNUCKLE-KNOCKING begins - but it is MUTED. SIMON and HOARE and the other CONSERVATIVE PLOTTERS all l to CHAMBERLAIN, as he — - puts his WHITE HANDKERCHIEF back in his BREAST POCKET!! The TORIES sit back - NONE APPLAUD.  26.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: CHAMBERLAIN, attempting to catch his breath, sits on a be looking across the rose in bloom so ripe they’re almost rotten. HALIFAX sees, then approaches CHAMBERLAIN.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: “Our policy is to wage war--At all costs--No survival”. Winston is incapable of pronouncing the word peace, let alone engaging in peace talks. He sits next to CHAMBERLAIN.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Awful, the thought that I shall never see my country at peace again.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: Neville? CHAMBERLAIN turns and faces HALIFAX - ashen faced.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: I have cancer.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: Oh Neville.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Winston must be removed from office.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: A vote of “no confidence”.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: If we can get him to declare that he refuses to consider a negotiated peace with Germany then perhaps you and I will have grounds to resign. The party wont stand for that, you’re still the chairman for heavens sake, that will force a vote of “no confidence” in his leadership and he’1ll be finished.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: And would you agree to be Prime Minister?  27.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: With Winston out of the way ... who can say, but the important thing, Neville, is that your policies, of peace and the protection of this nation, would be back on the table.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: On record.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: He must declare on record his refusal to engage in peace talks, we must have it in writing. HALIFAX’s eyes glisten with renewed purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH LAYTON makes her way to work, but today it’s a location - the grand TREASURY BUILDING in WHITEHALL, crossing, through traffic, Horse Guards Road and entering through the pillared main doors...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ECU - Elizabeth’s hand signs the Official Secrets Act whi is duly stamped. An elderly CIVIL SERVANT hands her a security pass. JOHN EVANS meets ELIZABETH in the lobby and leads her dow an INCONSPICUOUS DOOR where a SOLDIER checks her security pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EVANS leads ELIZABETH down a narrow staircase that leads the SECRET WAR-ROOMS, the underground nerve centre of BRI HIGH COMMAND. But the place is very humble, low ceiling and narrow hallways, the rooms small. No hint of luxury here. Auster Britain.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN EVANS
dialogues.text: Follow me.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What goes on down here?  28.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN EVANS
dialogues.text: That’s a need to know. And you don’t. JOHN EVANS keeps walking at a brisk pace through the telephonists room. ELIZABETH, clocking her surroundings, notices a door with dial lock that reads “VACANT”.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: The lavatory?

dialogues.speaker: EVANS
dialogues.text: For the PM’s use only. EVANS leads her down the corridor, through a narrow room bunk beds...John Evans gestures towards them.

dialogues.speaker: EVANS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sleeping quarters, for when you miss the last train. They pass the MAP ROOM -

dialogues.speaker: JOHN EVANS
dialogues.text: That’s the Map Room. No women allowed.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH LAYTON
dialogues.text: What department is this?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN EVANS
dialogues.text: Indiscretion in conversation, or any other form, within or without these rooms regarding what happens here is a statutory offense and punishable by up to two years imprisonment with hard labour. Clear?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Crystal.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN EVANS
dialogues.text: Good. Elizabeth follows Evans as they stop at the War Cabinet R JOHN EVANS (CONT’D) That's the War Cabinet room--never! Don’t mean to be rough on you but them’s the rules. They arrive at the TYPISTS POOL ROOM, full of NINE bust TYPISTS.  29. JOHN EVANS (CONT’D) This is the typists room, you are allowed in here.

dialogues.speaker: TYPISTS
dialogues.text: (In Unison) Good Morning Sir. And then indicates another Room - the door is ajar, its n bigger than a shoe-box!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN EVANS
dialogues.text: And here’s you. ELIZABETH enters the tiny, windowless room not much bigge than a cupboard, containing only a desk and a chair.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: She arranges her effects - a BLACK PEN, a RED PEN and a H PUNCH on her desk, and then sets carefully a PHOTOGRAPH o HANDSOME SOLDIER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CHIEFS OF STAFF brief WINSTON: IRONSIDE for the ARMY, DOWDING (a New Zealander) for the AIR FORCE, and a NAVAL ADMIRAL (DUDLEY POUND). CHAMBERLAIN and HALIFAX are also present - as other OFFIC all crowd in and look up at - THREE LARGE OPERATIONS MAPS of EUROPE hang on three diffe walls, each full of pins and strings to show positions - for the ARMY, ONE for the NAVY, ONE for the AIR-WAR. Down the centre of the room runs a long table bearing MULTIPLE TELEPHONES of different colors which are always RINGING...and being answered by OFFICERS of the three services. The BRIEFING begins in front of - the ARMY MAP - showing (with pins and colored string) how far WESTWARD the GERMA LINE has advanced.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: Belgium and Holland may fall any hour.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: The French?  30.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: The entire French ninth army--some two hundred thousand men--have capitulated.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: All of them?!

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: Capitulated. Surrendered. Deserted. It was a rout. All our land forces, roughly 300,000 men, are now in full retreat.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (to DOWDING) Air-cover? For our troops?

dialogues.speaker: AIR MARSHALL DOWDING
dialogues.text: The Luftwaffe control the skies. We simply don’t have enough planes to challenge them. In fact, I strongly recommend we stop sending our precious fighter-planes to be wasted in France--save them for our own defence. WINSTON moves to the NAVAL MAP, showing WARSHIP DEPLOYMENTS...

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: And our navy--sits idle, neutralized, useless.

dialogues.speaker: NAVAL ADMIRAL POUND
dialogues.text: Our fleets no sooner come within their range than we come under blistering air attack.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Their speed is devastating. WINSTON returns to the ARMY MAP -

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: Panzer tanks. Plunging rapidly westward, through the centre.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: But they will have to pause for fuel supplies. IRONSIDE looks at GENERAL ISMAY.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: Ismay?  31.

dialogues.speaker: ISMAY
dialogues.text: This is not the last war, Sir. Their tanks can stop for fuel at a petrol station.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Petrol station?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: The road to Paris now lies open. 7 million refugees are on the move. Collectively we are looking at the collapse of Western Europe in a few days.

dialogues.speaker: ISMAY
dialogues.text: Should the public be told?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Not yet. First, we must rouse our old friends to an heroic resistance. France must be saved. CAMERA moves in on the MAP... Over this, we start to dissolve in - - footage of a FLAMINGO PASSENGER PLANE in flight - - as the MAP itself dissolves into - - a real rural LANDSCAPE, as seen from above...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON’s FLAMINGO PASSENGER PLANE flies over FRENCH FIEL The PLANE is soon joined by two SPITFIRE FIGHTER ESCORTS, on each wing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see pilots in the cockpit looks down, a drink is poure and is taken to Winston as he looks down - His face goes grey as he sees - for the first time - CIVILIAN REFUGEES, long meandering columns of desperate humanity. On BOARD with WINSTON - ISMAY, DOWDING and IRONSIDE. The SHOCK of this plays on his face. WINSTON’s POV of: the vast tragedy. Amongst straggling vagabonds and columns of refugees. Signs of the GERMAN conquest - abandoned TANKS and ARTILLERY stand in flames.  32. CLOSE ON: A YOUNG REFUGEE BOY (his POV) looks up at WINST PLANE. He holds his left hand up to his left eye to look the plane.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: This can’t go on. Must not.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. FRENCH AIRCRAFT HANGER
dialogues.text: A LARGE DELEGATION of CIVILIANS and MILITARY await WINSTO as WINSTON alights the PLANE and approaches down a long R CARPET. PRIME MINISTER REYNAUD steps forward and shakes WINSTON’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (to REYNAUD) Brace yourselves, I am about to add to your terrible suffering-- by speaking French. They sit at a long table in the hangar. WINSTON (CONT’D) (in bad FRENCH) Bien que notre situation soit trés grave ce n'est pas la premiére fois que nous faisons face 4 une crise, ensemble. Subtitles: Although our plight is grave, this was not the first time we has been in a crisis together.

dialogues.speaker: REYNAUD
dialogues.text: Perhaps in English, Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (after a moment's offence) We have--we have survived crises before, and I am confident we will survive this one. Tell me how you plan to counter-attack.

dialogues.speaker: REYNAUD
dialogues.text: There is no plan. Silence - then...

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (in FRENCH) You must counter-attack. Premier, you must! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in ENGLISH) You must counter-attack! Vous devez contrattaquer! Il le faut! Gentlemen--I do not believe this Panzer breakthrough is a real invasion.

dialogues.speaker: REYNAUD
dialogues.text: Not a real invasion? Stupefied looks from the FRENCH and ISMAY alike.

dialogues.speaker: DALADIER
dialogues.text: (in FRENCH) Tell this to the families of the dead perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: REYNAUD
dialogues.text: We sincerely appreciate your efforts and optimism, but--we have lost. WINSTON seems unable/unwilling to process this -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: As long as--as their tanks are not supported by infantry units they are merely little flags, stuck on the map, because the tank crews are unable to support themselves. No, I refuse to see in this spectacular raid of the German tanks a real invasion. Silence to this. Is WINSTON losing his mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON’s FLAMINGO takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REYNAUD and DALADIER, side by side in the car, watch WINSTON’s FLAMINGO climbing into the sky -

dialogues.speaker: REYNAUD
dialogues.text: (in FRENCH, with SUBTITLES) Il Devine! Delusional! (He's delusional)

dialogues.speaker: DALADIER
dialogues.text: C’est Anglais (He’s English.)  34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIR JOHN SIMON and LORD LONDONDERRY walk and talk along t libary gallery -

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SIMON
dialogues.text: He’s an actor. In love with the sound of his own voice.

dialogues.speaker: LONDONDERRY
dialogues.text: Oh I love to listen to him--but we must never take his advice. Has a hundred ideas a day. Four are good, the other 96 downright dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SIMON
dialogues.text: His father was a great orator but...

dialogues.speaker: LONDONDERRY
dialogues.text: Until he lost his mind to syphilis -

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN SIMON
dialogues.text: How nations suffer for the sins of their fathers. Across the AISLE, STANHOPE is also talking about CHURCHIL with SIR SAMUEL HOARE -

dialogues.speaker: STANHOPE
dialogues.text: My opinion? At this critical juncture for the empire, we have a drunkard at the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: SIR SAMUEL HOARE
dialogues.text: Wakes with a scotch, bottle of champagne at lunch, another at dinner, brandy and port till the wee hours...I wouldn’t let him borrow my bicycle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KINGSLEY WOOD is talking to a COLLEAGUE -

dialogues.speaker: KINGSLEY WOOD
dialogues.text: He’s a Conservative, who defects to the Liberals--lobs grenades at us for 10 years--then flops Conservative again, as it bloody suits him! Sorry, but--he stands for one thing: himself!  35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HALIFAX is sitting with KING GEORGE VI.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: We might have to replace him, Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Replace him?!

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: We must strive for peace--for every son and daughter of this land so that we may emerge from this crisis with something recognisable as ‘home.'

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Spoken like a true Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YELLOW POWDERED EGGS are being MIXED with WATER, then fri then slopped onto a plate as SCRAMBLED EGGS. On a BREAKFA TRAY (once more)are set - (in rapid cuts) BACON and POWDE EGGS, SCOTCH and SODA, a GLASS of WINE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN EVANS stands outside the LOO (whose door is closed), with a note-pad and pen, ready to record WINSTON’s instructions.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN EVANS
dialogues.text: Sir, you need to reply to the Lord Privy Seal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON sits on the TOILET, reading a French newspaper wh front page shows a picture of FRENCH SOLDIER with his arm around his FRENCH SWEETHEART, holding up his fingers in a FOR-VICTORY gesture (palm-outward). The headline is “V PO LA VICTOIRE”. Winston is sitting on the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: The Privy Seal?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN EVANS
dialogues.text: Yes sir?  36.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (reading) “V for Victory” WINSTON closes the newspaper, stands -— WINSTON (CONT’D) Tell the Lord Privy Seal -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: - tell him I’m sealed in the Privy - We hear a flush and then WINSTON appears, wearing his pin silk dressing-gown.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - and I can only deal with one shit at a time! He goes into the bedroom, followed by EVANS, where we fin ELIZABETH LAYTON, typing at the nearby desk, and -— ANTHONY EDEN, seated in a chair beside the bed, reading WINSTON’S TYPED SPEECH... WINSTON (CONT’D) Don’t spare me, Anthony--be frank.

dialogues.speaker: EDEN
dialogues.text: Mmmmm. As EDEN reads, WINSTON stares at him, awaiting his reacti

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (to EDEN) I think it’s rather good. The ending especially. When EDEN says nothing the wait becomes agonizing. EDEN finishes reading the speech, turns over the last page to if there is more on the back. There isn’t. WINSTON waits for the verdict. EDEN takes off his glasses slowly and looks up at a hopeful WINSTON -

dialogues.speaker: EDEN
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: You don’t think so, what?  37.

dialogues.speaker: EDEN
dialogues.text: You’re suggesting we’re--somehow-- winning. (beat) We're not.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: No but...it will inspire them.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t understand - Winston, I know -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (stubbornly) - no, no, no. I am going to imbue them, Anthony, with a spirit of feeling they don’t yet know they have! Silence. Stalemate. EDEN looks gravely concerned.

dialogues.speaker: EDEN
dialogues.text: You asked my opinion. I caution against it. WINSTON stares at his trusted ally, his hopes fading, unt he snaps his finger, pointing at EDEN -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Cicero! He’s on the move again - heading out of the bedroom, with EVANS and LAYTON, and finally EDEN, forced to follow...

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: “Live as", “Live as brave men" — da,da,da - “and if fortune is adverse, something, something, something He then enters the -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: As he looks for his book in the library he finds CLEMMIE...STRESSED, struggling to cope, busily writing CHEQUES.  38. WINSTON (CONT’D) Cat--my copy of Cicero. Did you shelve it?

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: Did you hear what I said?!

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: We're broke.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Everybody out! Get out! He shooes JOHN EVANS, ELIZABETH and EDEN from the room as they were cats.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: I dare not write another cheque.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I’‘1l economise - only four cigars a day!

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: You're insufferable! (beat) Was there something else? Anything?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Yes, my love for you.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: How much have you had to drink this morning? He goes to her, drawing up a chair, close -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I see you now as I first saw you in nineteen hundred and four across a crowded dance-floor. I simply stood- -speechless.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: I must have been very beautiful to have achieved that miraculous effect.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Four years till we saw each other again.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: They went by in an absolute flash.  39.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: You didn’t lack for admirers. Your fidéle serviteur in Sidney Peel.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: Brilliant man.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Lionel Earle.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: Wonderful dancer.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: And then--at Lady St Hellier’s dinner party--who should show up?

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: Pig. (little snort)

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: The same. They look at each other, their faces very close.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: Are we terribly old?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m afraid you are. She LAUGHS and pushes him away. Winston takes her hand. WINSTON (CONT’D) Will you hear me read my speech for tonight's broadcast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON emerges and is accosted by... the PRESS.

dialogues.speaker: TERENCE BIRKEMP
dialogues.text: Prime Minister - the situation in France - Is it true we’re in full retreat? Is France lost? He fires the REPORTER a steely look of rebuke and then sp faces their CAMERAS, takes his CIGAR out of his mouth wit INDEX and SECOND finger and makes, for the CAMERAS, his f ever V-FOR-VICTORY SIGN (but PALM-INWARD, the RUDE VERSIO WINSTON crosses the road, practising a tongue-twister as enters the TREASURY.  40. INT. WINSTON’S OFFICE/ WAR ROOMS - NIGHT WINSTON sitting on his bed, is AGITATED, UNEASY, UNSURE n about the speech he is to deliver on RADIO. ELIZABETH LAYTON sits at a desk in the corner holding fil and paperwork. Two MICROPHONES sit on a table. An ACTOR also stands by. Producer guides Winston to his desk.

dialogues.speaker: BBC PRODUCER
dialogues.text: So--if you will sit here - at your desk

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Mmmmm. WINSTON sits, studying with CONCERN the SPEECH lying on t table in front of him, and taking out his PEN.

dialogues.speaker: BBC PRODUCER
dialogues.text: - and speak slowly and clearly. Into the microphone. WINSTON starts to jot last-minute CHANGES to the SPEECH. Increasingly PRESSURISED, he CROSSES OUT the CHANGES he j made, and tries to write alternatives. He’s clearly ina state. BBC PRODUCER (CONT’D) So--if you are ready--on the stroke of 9 the light will go red, and we shall go live to the nation. Nine O Clock. Red light. You begin. Yes? But WINSTON isn’t ready. He’s too busy trying to rewrite speech The SWEEP SECOND HAND on the WALL CLOCK approaches 12. The PRODUCER, and ELIZABETH, become very concerned now as last seconds vanish - BBC PRODUCER (CONT’D) Prime Minister? Are we ready?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (to himself) One moment, one moment —

dialogues.speaker: BBC PRODUCER
dialogues.text: We are going live. Prime -—

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (exploding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This eruption stuns the PRODUCER and ELIZABETH. WINSTON’s hand, holding the PEN, shakes now with indecisi as he fails to think of the right words in time -

dialogues.speaker: BBC PRODUCER
dialogues.text: Four--three--two--one... On the stroke of 9 pm, the light goes RED, bathing him in light. They are LIVE. SILENCE. TOTAL SILENCE. The PRODUCER is now in a panic. WINSTON seems frozen for a second, until - WINSTON takes a breath and begins...

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: “I speak to you for the first time as Prime Minister in a solemn hour for the life of our country, of our Empire, of our allies, and, above all, of the cause of Freedom. A tremendous battle is raging in France and Flanders.” ELIZABETH sighs relief, then follows on her carbon copy, mouthing the words, many of which she knows by heart. CAMERA follows the WIRES that lead out of the office, dow the corridor, and into the TRANSMITTER ROOM. Reveal BBC R Recorder men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK to reveal: The KING, looking up from the PAPER, he listens to WINSTON’s speech on the radio, and studies FRAMED FAMILY PHOTOS of his CHILDREN...Princesses ELIZABE and MARGARET.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: “The Germans...by a remarkable combination of air bombing and heavily armored tanks, have broken through the French defenses north of the Maginot Line, and strong columns of their armoured vehicles are ravaging the open country...” CLOSE ON: NEWSPAPER - the HEADLINE reads: IN CONTROL, SAY FRENCH Despite Nazi Raid  42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HALIFAX sits at the table, a minister standing behind him they listen to Winston’s radio address

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: “,..which for the first day or two was without defenders...But!...I have invincible confidence in the French Army and its leaders. Only a very small part of that splendid Army has yet been heavily engaged; and only a very small part of France has yet been invaded...Side by side, the British and French peoples--have advanced...” HALIFAX is disgusted by this DISTORTION of the facts.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: “Advanced”?! How bloody dare he!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AERIAL SHOT OF: the BRITISH and FRENCH armies in retreat leaving behind SMOKING TRUCKS and ABANDONED ARTILLERY. TRACKING OVER this ravaged landscape, we see-

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: - the abstracted landscape of a human CORPSE...

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: “,..the British and French peoples-—- have advanced--to rescue not only Europe, but mankind from the foulest and most soul-destroying tyranny which has ever darkened and stained the pages of history. .-.-until an EYE is revealed in CLOSE-UP, staring into CA INT. WINSTON’S OFFICE/ WAR ROOMS - NIGHT CLOSE-UP ON: the RED RECORDING LIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: “But now one bond unites us all - to wage war until victory is won, and never to surrender ourselves to servitude and shame, whatever the cost and the agony may be...Conquer we must, as conquer we shall.” CLOSE-UP ON: WINSTON’s FACE...  43.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH LAYTON
dialogues.text: Well done, sir. WINSTON sits back - UNHAPPY. CLOSE-UP ON: the RED RECORDING LIGHT goes off. The BROADC is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLEMMIE turns off the RADIO, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON, UNHAPPY, walks up to a DOOR, enters it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - then walks down the long tunnel (connecting the WAR ROO with DOWNING STREET) until, at its end, he enters an ELEV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - WINSTON rides the ELEVATOR upward -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - WINSTON exits the ELEVATOR, and begins to climb the sta

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: You did marvelously.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: For the last ten years I was the only one who told them the truth. Until tonight. There’s no advance. It’s a shambles. We’re in full retreat.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: Would you be serving them tonight by denying them sleep, terrifying their children?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Even if the terror is coming?!

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: Because it’s coming! There is time enough for truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods, accepting this. He walks off, still anxious. She watches him go, worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front page of a newspaper: a PHOTO of WINSTON doing h FOR VICTORY SIGN (palm inward). ELIZABETH LAYTON, leaning by the door, reading the paper. At her side stands another typist, SYBIL, reading another copy of the same PAPER -— ELIZABETH is giggling - WINSTON passes the doorway in the corridor, then re-appea

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: What’s so funny?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Prime Minister sir -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Go on. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH steps out into the corridor so they can have so privacy -

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Not sure if you know this but-- the way you are doing your V For Victory sign--well, in the poorer quarters that gesture means--something else.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: What does it mean?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Wouldn’t like to say sir.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I was captured by the Boer. I spent time in a South African prison.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Up yer’ bum. Sir.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Up yer’ bum? WINSTON roars with LAUGHTER - which sets ELIZABETH laughi  45.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: The way you do it, sir. Yes sir. (demonstrates) But if you turn it around - (palm out) - that’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Wouldn’t like millions of people to take it the wrong way. WINSTON steps away, still chuckling -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Up yer’ bum! INT. BUCKINGHAM PALACE / WINSTON’S OFFICE, WAR ROOMS - DA KING GEORGE speaks into the TELEPHONE -

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Don’t wish to take too much of your time. (pause) I heard you--on the--wireless.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Was I comprehensible?

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: The public need to be led, not misled--not left to work it out for them-themselves.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Right. Will that be all, your majesty?

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Yes. Good day Prime Minister. (click) WINSTON puts down the PHONE and turns to EVANS.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I believe I’ve just recieved a royal rap on the knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRESENT: 17 PERSONS. The Main War Cabinet, minus WINSTON (CHAMBERLAIN, HALIFAX, GREENWOOD, ATLEE) and the FOLLOWIN

dialogues.speaker: DOWDING, IRONSIDE, BRIDGES, ISMAY, NICHOLL, WILKINSON
dialogues.text: CABINET SECRETARY BRIDGES is helping to seat everyone as move around the table looking for their placement card.

dialogues.speaker: CABINET SECRETARY BRIDGES
dialogues.text: (indicating to HALIFAX's seat) Foreign Minister? A NEW MAP shows the NEW POSITIONS of BRITISH TROOPS. SURR at DUNKIRK. Finally, WINSTON enters, shakes the hands of IRONSIDE and first, but has less enthusiasm for ATTLEE and GREENWOOD, nothing for CHAMBERLAIN and HALIFAX, who do not expect to their hands shaken.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Tiny, good to see you. (to ISMAY) Pug. Welcome to the War Cabinet, such as we are. (to ALL) Please, sit. He sits. WINSTON (CONT’D) War is usually a catalogue of blunders, and this one is proving no exception. (beat) General - its all yours.

dialogues.speaker: IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: You have this morning’s report in front of you -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Yes. General -

dialogues.speaker: IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: - if you turn to page 3 - Ummm - so on page 3 - are we all Looking at page 3? - no, the other document - second paragraph down - WINSTON, agitated, reeling from the royal reprimand, taps wedding ring finger on the side of his chair impatiently

dialogues.speaker: GREENWOOD
dialogues.text: Second?  47.

dialogues.speaker: IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: Yes, the second--no, page - WINSTON can stand it no longer - Silence -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (his patience snapping) Edmund!--why don’t you just tell us- -please--in your own words-- what kind of mess we are looking at here. What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: Right. (beat) As of 2200 hours last night--the Germans have encircled sixty British, Belgian and French divisions. On our part all our forces under Lord Gort have now withdrawn, or are trying to withdraw, to the French coast, to Dunkirk, where we cannot reach them. Ships sunk by the Nazis block the harbour entrance and the Luftwaffe control the skies above.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: How many of our men are trapped?

dialogues.speaker: IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: All of them. (pause) Our nation’s entire professional soldiery. And... (pause) .-..we can see no clear way to rescue them.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: General--are you telling me that we shall have lost the British army by the next few days?

dialogues.speaker: IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: That’s correct.

dialogues.speaker: ATTLEE
dialogues.text: What are the French doing?

dialogues.speaker: IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: Premiere Raynaud sent a radio message. He expects the defence of Paris will soon fail.  48.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: We must counter-attack. Anyone? (silence) Surely -

dialogues.speaker: IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: The German forces are superior in every regard and are only fifty miles from the coast. They are pushing us into the sea.

dialogues.speaker: ATTLEE
dialogues.text: Fifty miles! Good God!

dialogues.speaker: GREENWOOD
dialogues.text: For a German tank, two days.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: They must not reach the sea! Not before we evacuate our men! General Ismay? What have you got for us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looks at ISMAY.

dialogues.speaker: ISMAY
dialogues.text: As it stands--I cannot see that we have much hope of getting any of our forces out in time. A gasp in the cabinet. WINSTON takes this news badly.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Not a man? We cannot be so totally at their mercy! REACTION HALIFAX: Only just holding his tongue. He looks CHAMBERLAIN, who does not maintain the look. WINSTON (CONT’D) General. What is our next step?

dialogues.speaker: IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure, sir, that we have one. Silence. A pall settles. ISMAY looks at IRONSIDE, who say nothing. CHAMBERLAIN and HALIFAX also exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: So? So where are we to look for salvation? (silence) Anyone? Come on! Speak!

dialogues.speaker: IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: We still have a Garrison at Calais. 25 miles to the west.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Well why didn’t you say so?! How Many men do we have there?

dialogues.speaker: IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: 4,000. More or less.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Then have them go east--engage with the German columns moving on Dunkirk. Buy us some time. Draw the Nazi focus away from Dunkirk whilst we execute a maritime evacuation of our forces. Ironside--is that possible?

dialogues.speaker: IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: It would mean a huge sacrifice.

dialogues.speaker: ATTLEE
dialogues.text: Four thousand young men!

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: To save 300,000! (pause) Under whose command is the Calais Garrison?

dialogues.speaker: ISMAY
dialogues.text: Brigadier Nicholson. Silence. The burden falls on Winston...

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Very well--tell... A hint of UNCERTAINTY here, as WINSTON taps his SIGNET RI on the wooden arm of his chair. WINSTON (CONT’D) ...tell--Nicholson--that it is of the greatest importance to this island that his garrison draw the enemy’s tanks and artillery and bombers away from Dunkirk--invite their wrath--and to--to fight on if needs be until--until the destruction of his command. A PALL settles over the room. Almost a GASP.

dialogues.speaker: ATTLEE
dialogues.text: It’s suicide. HALIFAX, emotions rising, can stay silent no longer.  50.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: Prime Minister! I have reservations...

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Who is free of reservations?

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: -..-about such a fateful course when we have the option of a peace offer.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: What peace offer?!

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: The Italians have offered to mediate between ourselves and Germany. And I indicated that provided our liberty and independence were assured, we would consider any proposal.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: With Hitler holding the whip hand do you really think he would honour our liberty and independence?

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: It would be in his interest to do so. He -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: The only thing to do is to show that maniac that he cannot conquer this country, and for that we need an army. General, tell Brigadier Nicholson, “The Germans must not reach the sea! Not before we get our boys off that bloody beach!" (pause) I take full responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (temper exploding) REALLY! YES! It is the reason I sit in this chair!

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: Surely--before we send 4,000 men to their graves, we must explore -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (frustrated) What is this?!  51.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: What is your mind on the principle of peace talks? Do we take it for example, that you preclude yourself from even considering engaging in such negotiations? A TENSE SILENCE. ANGLE ON: the TWO SECRETARIES, pencil’s raised, waiting t record WINSTON’s reply. WINSTON, aware that history is listening, senses a TRAP -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I should like to speak to Viscount Halifax and Mr Chamberlain alone. (to IRONSIDE) Issue the order to the Calais Garrison. Confirm it has been done. (to BRIDGES) Bridges! You too! Out! Hop it! BRIDGES puts down his pencil. Consternation from those departing at this breach of protocol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of the line of unneeded WAR CABINET members fi out, comes the disgruntled BRIDGES with his TWO SECRETARI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON lights his CIGAR, and takes his time, slowly appr the HALIFAX seated at the back of the room.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: Winston. We are facing certain defeat on land--the annihilation of our army--and imminent invasion! We must be rational!

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: We are a sea-going nation. Have been since the Bronze Age. The Channel is ours--our moat--our battlement and the German doesn’t recognise an expanse of water greater than a bloody lake! They have first to reach this island -  52.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: - which will be full of terrified men, women and children, whom we have failed, despicably, in our duty of protection. Germany has won- -we are entirely defenceless -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: And who's fault is that ?! CHAMBERLAIN averts his face.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: - facing the largest army the world has seen. Furthermore, once France falls, Germany can concentrate on aircraft production and they will then have the French fleet as well! What is to stop Hitler then? Words? Words, Winston? Words alone? (beat) If you will not permit any talk of peace then I will be forced - CHAMBERLAIN steps in, to stop Halifax from resigning.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Might we not allow Edward simply to meet the Italian ambassador, Bastianini--discuss their possible role as mediators between us and Germany, and find out their price? WINSTON is calmed by CHAMBERLAIN’s manner -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Bastianini? Ha! A man about whom we might say there is less to him than meets the eye. WINSTON looks at HALIFAX, and sighs - WINSTON (CONT’D) I remain opposed to any negotiations -

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: - of course -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: - which might lead to a derogation of our rights and power.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: AS DO WE ALL! There is no question that our sovereignty is non- negotiable!  53.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Winston? With nowhere left to turn - WINSTON gives a slow inclinat of the head, and then - NODS. CHAMBERLAIN (CONT’D) Good. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: -.-but! No-one outside this room must ever know.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON walks through the corridors - then approaches and opens a SMALL LAVATORY DOOR. As he enters - CLOSE ON: The door’s lock, which slides from “VACANT” to “ENGAGED”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, it’s no LAVATORY. It is actually - a secret PRIVA TELEPHONE SYSTEM, linking WINSTON with the ROOSEVELT WHIT HOUSE. WINSTON, seated, holding the receiver, takes a few moment before he lifts the phone to his ear -—

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Mr President?

dialogues.speaker: ROOSEVELT
dialogues.text: Winston!

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: How are you Franklin?

dialogues.speaker: ROOSEVELT
dialogues.text: Fine. Fine. How are you Prime Minister?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I am phoning about--about your Navy ships. If you were to loan us just 50 of your older Destroyers I feel sure —

dialogues.speaker: ROOSEVELT
dialogues.text: Ah! Yes!  54.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON ROOSEVELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - even 40 would - Well I - ROOSEVELT (CONT’D) - I did ask around, but just not possible I’m afraid. The Neutrality Act we signed last year has tied my hands. Just can’t swing it. I tried.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Then--can I--do I have your permission to send an aircraft carrier to pick up the P-40 fighter planes we purchased? Mr President.

dialogues.speaker: ROOSEVELT
dialogues.text: (wincing, hating not being able to help) You got me there again. New law-- preventing trans-shipment of military equipment.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: But we’ve paid for them--with the money we borrowed from you!

dialogues.speaker: ROOSEVELT
dialogues.text: (anguished) So sorry, Winston.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I need not impress upon you the trouble faced by the Western Hemisphere. Without your support, in some fashion... Silence. A tense moment...

dialogues.speaker: ROOSEVELT
dialogues.text: I know. I know. You are on my mind day and night. (pause) Look. We could--possibly... But words fail the hampered ROOSEVELT and his voice trail off.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Mr President--we are facing the gravest odds!  55.

dialogues.speaker: ROOSEVELT
dialogues.text: .-.-we could take your planes to about a mile from the Canadian border--and then if you send across a team of horses from Canada-- nothing motorized--then you could pull ‘em over the border yourself. How does that sound?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Horses? You said “a team of horses"?

dialogues.speaker: ROOSEVELT
dialogues.text: I guess you could push ‘em yourself. The damn things have wheels. Up to you. WINSTON is speechless - ROOSEVELT (CONT’D) We could do that. (silence) Prime Minister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON covers the PHONE, bunches his fist, swallows his RAGE, and then speaks again, as calmly as he can-

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Anything you can do at this time would be welcome.

dialogues.speaker: ROOSEVELT
dialogues.text: Goodnight to you Winston. (feeling WINSTON's pain) It must be late there?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: In more ways than you could possibly know. He puts down the phone and sits back in his chair - stunn fuming. But as he stews, he slowly - slowly - conceives a idea, a new IDEA!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON enters and strides past the staff, making for the LARGE MAP of EUROPE. He puts his finger on the FRENCH COA at DUNKIRK, encircled by RED THREAD. And then looks at ENGLAND, the COAST, and then taps DOVER on the map. He turns, sees the DOZEN colorful TELEPHONES and addresse

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Get me Vice-Admiral Ramsay on one of these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIGH AERIAL of the CASTLE atop the famous WHITE-CLIFFS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ADMIRAL RAMSAY is woken by a STAFFER.

dialogues.speaker: STAFFER
dialogues.text: Admiral Ramsay?

dialogues.speaker: RAMSAY
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: STAFFER
dialogues.text: It’s the Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAMSAY, on the PHONE with WINSTON.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bertie? I hope I didn’t wake you.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSAY
dialogues.text: Of course not. I was just reading the Bible. (INTERCUT, as necessary with - )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON, on a PHONE, studies the COAST of ENGLAND.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Exodus? (smiles) We need to evacuate our boys, Bertie. The Navy is saying that with one cruiser and six destroyers, and with the Luftwaffe controlling the skies above, we'll be lucky to get 10% out. I want you to order an assembly of boats.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSAY
dialogues.text: Boats?  57.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Yes. Civilian boats, as many as you can get your hands on. Country’s full of boats--let’s put ‘em to use. Bertie? You there?

dialogues.speaker: RAMSAY
dialogues.text: (sceptical) Rrrr-ight.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: - anyone with a pleasure craft bigger than 30 foot that can get to France. Longley's clipper, Fearnley's gin palace, any half- rotten fishing boat that’1l float.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSAY
dialogues.text: Mmmm—hmmm. WINSTON senses BERTIE’s reticence...and makes a different appeal...

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Help me stage this thing, Bertie. We must at least try to bring some of our boys home. After a pause -

dialogues.speaker: RAMSAY
dialogues.text: I will have the BBC issue the order. WINSTON starts to put the phone down, and then remembers something -—

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Oh-- Bertie--still there?

dialogues.speaker: RAMSAY
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: We need a name--for this Operation. RAMSAY looks around him - a blazon on a generator says “DYNAMO” .

dialogues.speaker: CAPTION
