dialogues.text: WINSTON walks with EDEN, but then they pass an OFFICER’s OFFICE, whose DOOR is open - and it’s then that he hears, his fury, the sound of a RADIO playing a SPEECH BY HITLER WINSTON PULLS THE DOOR SHUT, silencing the dictator.  58. WINSTON and EDEN look at each other, then walk on, and st before entering the WAR CABINET ROOM, (as if before takin the stage). WINSTON takes a deep breath and tries to shak off his worries. Only then does he enter, followed by EDE

dialogues.speaker: WAR CABINET MEETING 2.
dialogues.text: PRESENT: 17 PERSONS. The Main War Cabinet (CHURCHILL, CHAMBERLAIN, HALIFAX, GREENWOOD, ATLEE) and the FOLLOWING

dialogues.speaker: DOWDING, IRONSIDE, BRIDGES, ISMAY, NICHOLL, WILKINSON
dialogues.text: A tense atmosphere - faces riven with doubt. The CABINET standing, conferring anxiously with each other...... but fall silent when WINSTON and ANTHONY EDEN enter.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Good day. I’ve asked the Minister for War to join us. HALIFAX and CHAMBERLAIN share a look - this doesn’t bode well. All sit. WINSTON looks around the table - sees the fear a doubt and nervousness in his CABINET right away. WINSTON starts to tap his SIGNET RING on his right hand o the wooden arm of his chair, until - WINSTON (CONT’D) Obviously--we are in a dangerous situation. But - I am assured by the French Premiere that while some German tank units have reached the sea, the situation generally seems to be well in hand. No-one looks at all convinced by this - CLOSE ON: the wooden arm of WINSTON’s chair - the varnish worn away from three weeks of such anxious tapping.

dialogues.speaker: GREENWOOD
dialogues.text: Prime Minister. You don’t believe that.

dialogues.speaker: ATTLEE
dialogues.text: France will fall.

dialogues.speaker: GREENWOOD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ATTLEE
dialogues.text: And invasion of this island will follow.  59. WINSTON changes the subject -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: What news from Calais?

dialogues.speaker: ATTLEE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: The Garrison attacked, but was forced back and is now surrounded on all sides. They are being shelled and bombed mercilessly. Casualties are at sixty percent. The CABINET all shake their heads - all look to have lost FAITH in WINSTON. CHAMBERLAIN nods at HALIFAX -

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: On the question of peace talks -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: - We must hold our nerve. Signal only that we are going to fight it out to the end. A peace offer telegraphs our weakness. CHURCHILL looks to EDEN for support -

dialogues.speaker: EDEN
dialogues.text: Agreed.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: And even if we were beaten--we should be no worse off than we should be if we were now to abandon the struggle. Let us therefore avoid being dragged down the slippery slope with talk of a negotiated peace.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: Slippery slope? The only -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON HALIFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -I suspect Germany and Italy - -the only slippery slope -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: -want to get us so deeply involved in negotiations that we should be unable to turn back!

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: Oh nonsense! Bastianini informed me-  60.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: The approach -

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: - The only slippery slope -

dialogues.speaker: WHILE I AM INTERRUPTING YOU
dialogues.text: When I chose my War Cabinet I took great care to surround myself with old rivals. I may have overdone it. Only GREENWOOD and ATTLEE and EDEN smile. HALIFAX and CHAMBERLAIN look exasperated. WINSTON (CONT’D) Viscount Halifax--the approach you proposed is not only futile, but involves us in a deadly danger.

dialogues.speaker: ROMANTIC FANTASY OF FIGHTING TO THE
dialogues.text: END!!! What is “the end” if not the destruction of all? There is nothing heroic in going down fighting if it can be avoided. Nothing even remotely patriotic in death or glory if the odds are on the former; nothing inglorious in trying to shorten a war that we are clearly losing. WINSTON cannot bear this talk -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON HALIFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Europe is still - Europe is lost!

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And before our forces are wiped out completely this is the time to negotiate, in order to obtain the best conditions possible. It would not be in Hitler’s interests to insist on outrageous terms. He will know his own weaknesses. He will be reasonable. WINSTON cannot bear this talk -  61.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: When will the lesson be learned? How many more dictators must be wooed, appeased--Good God, given immense privileges, before we learn!--that you can’t reason with a tiger when your head is in its mouth! WINSTON rises and walks out. HALIFAX, escaping CHAMBERLAI grip on his forearm, alone chases WINSTON...into -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HALIFAX pursues WINSTON into the vestibule-

dialogues.speaker: PRIME MINISTER -
dialogues.text: WINSTON turns back to him - they are now enclosed in the vestibule.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Winston! Yesterday you gave permission for -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: What permission?

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: - for me to meet - HALIFAX (CONT’D) WINSTON - with Bastianini - - I sanctioned - WINSTON (CONT’D) - the theoretical ex-

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -ploration - - theoretical?! -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: - of what price Italy would ask. No more. I did not sanction-

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: If you will not allow any further exploration of a peace agreement, then--you will have my resignation.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Don’t be absurd. I need you Edward. You know I do!  62.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: I will not stand by to watch another generation of young men die at the bloody altar of your hubris!

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: And you would have us die as lambs!

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: Was Gallipoli not enough for you?!

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (angry) How dare you?! Our troops were chewing barbed wire in Flanders! I saw it! Opening a second front, outflanking the Turks, was a serious military idea - and it could've damn-well worked if - the Admirals and First Sea Lord hadn’‘t dithered away our element of surprise! Silence. WINSTON realises he’s gone too far. Totally lost poise. He calms himself. But too late. HALIFAX, undaunted fixes WINSTON with a cold judicial eye -

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: The choice is yours. You have 24 hours to enter into peace talks, or I resign. HALIFAX walks back into the war rooms. WINSTON, regretful his display of temper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON emerges from the ELEVATOR, to find - - the YOUNG CONSERVATIVE MP, ERNLE HASTINGS, waiting for at the bottom of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: ERNLE HASTINGS
dialogues.text: Prime Minister. I wonder if we might schedule you to address the Outer Cabinet? WINSTON climbs the stairs, without saying a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HALIFAX, energized, and CHAMBERLAIN, looking unwell, conf as CHAMBERLAIN dampens a handkerchief and dabs his head w cold water...  63.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: I told him. It shook him.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Imagine it did.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: Gave him 24 hours--I don’t expect him to agree, so I will resign first. You then join me. That’s critical if we are to trigger a revolt in the chamber. I’1l announce it. The King will back us. HALIFAX nods. CHAMBERLAIN now mentors him, paternally -

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Be sure of your motives, Edward. Country first! Country First always. Career third, fourth-- after family, and church - and, in your case (small smile) - fox hunting. Come. CHAMBERLAIN bravely leads an emotional HALIFAX out of the BATHROOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIGH-ANGLE WIDE-SHOT of LONDON - then PAN to reveal RADIO AERIALS, as we hear —

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: “Today, the Admiralty have made an Order requesting all owners of self- propelled pleasure craft, between 30' and 100' in length, to send all particulars to the Admiralty, immediately -—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON listens to the RADIO BROADCAST:

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: “— if they have not already been offered or requisitioned.” WINSTON turns off the RADIO, turns to face ELIZABETH LAYT who sits at her type-writer, waiting. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: (dictating) To Brigadier Nicholson, 30th Infantry Brigade. Calais. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CHURCHILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Every hour you continue to exist is of the greatest help to our forces at Dunkirk. Have the greatest possible admiration for your splendid stand. Your evacuation however--your evacuation will not, repeat not, take place. Signed... ELIZABETH LAYTON, has stopped typing. CHURCHILL, looks up and sees tears in her eyes. He goes t her, offering a handkerchief. CHURCHILL (CONT’D) Here. (softening) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH LAYTON
dialogues.text: May I be excused?

dialogues.speaker: CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: You may not. Tell me what this is about.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH LAYTON
dialogues.text: No-one tells us anything. It’s all classified and--we hear scraps and it’s worse than knowing nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: What would you like to know? She stares into his eyes -

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH LAYTON
dialogues.text: How many men will survive? He stares at her - it’s the great PUBLIC QUESTION. It deserves an answer.

dialogues.speaker: CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Come with me. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON leads ELIZABETH down the long tunnel -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - ELIZABETH follows WINSTON to the MAP-ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Come in.  65.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No. I’m not allowed in the Map Room.

dialogues.speaker: CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: You are now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She enters the MAP ROOM, which is manned with MALE person who look askance at ELIZABETH. WINSTON shows her the ARMY MAP of WESTERN EUROPE. The BRITISH FORCES are represented surrounded by GERMAN troops at the seaside town of DUNKIR She nods.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: The German army now controls every French port except Dunkirk, here--and Calais, here to the west, where a garrison is drawing fire and delaying the German advance on Dunkirk. WINSTON (CONT’D) At both points our troops are encircled. We’re still trying to clear Dunkirk harbour of wrecked ships so we can then land the boats we need to get our boys off those beaches, but enemy planes are attacking us constantly. Our only hope in Dunkirk is thick cloud cover to thwart these attacks, but-- the skies remain clear. Even then I am told we will need a miracle to get even 10% of our men out. She is shocked - WINSTON (CONT’D) Courage, Miss Layton--courage.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: How long have they got if we don’t rescue them?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: One, maybe two days. ISMAY enters - WINSTON (CONT’D) General?  66.

dialogues.speaker: ISMAY
dialogues.text: News from Calais, the 30th Infantry, sir. They've retreated to the town’s citadel... As a last and probably hopeless stand-the order “Everyman for himself’ has been given.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (As he exits) Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CITADEL rises, ancient and proud above the town, as - - a GERMAN RECONNAISSANCE PLANE flies a circle over the CITADEL and lays a CIRCLE OF WHITE SMOKE.

dialogues.speaker: ISMAY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: +». aS a last, and probably hopeless, stand. The order, ‘every man for himself’ has been given.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIGADIER NICHOLSON, surrounded by the DEAD and WOUNDED, reads the dispatch from CHURCHILL - grim reading. He lowe it, stricken, afraid, as he hears...the DRONE of 50 GERMA BOMBERS rising...coming closer...closer...He looks up int the dark skies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the POV of a GERMAN bomber, at high altitude - - the CIRCLE OF SMOKE comes beneath it, and in the middle the circle, perfectly targeted far below, the CITADEL. Into the CIRCLE of SMOKE the BOMBER drops its PAYLOAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ECU on: WINSTON’s EYES, as if -while staring at the map- is witness to this defeat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOMBS fall on the town, and at last the CITADEL itsel takes a DIRECT HIT. It crumbles, and falls...  67. INT. WINSTON’S STUDY / 10 DOWNING STREET - NIGHT ECU ON: A MILITARY DISPATCH, that reads: CALAIS FALLEN. NUMBERS OF DEAD OR CAPTURED UNCERTAIN. GENERAL GORT. Across the room, WINSTON is at his desk, immobile, nursin glass of whiskey and soda, as, - - CLEMMIE enters - and looks at him, with concern.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: (worried) Go to bed, Pig. He gives no reply -

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You must sleep.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Leave me, Clemmie.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: The opportunity for doing so passed a long time ago. She gets an idea, and exits urgently, leaving him alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON, in his SILK ROBE, still sits at his desk. The curtains are drawn. It’s MORNING. He walks to a TELEPHONE dials - ADMIRAL RAMSAY.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Bertie--what’s been the response?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: 5 SMALL CRAFT, arriving at DOVER - a packet boa yacht, a fishing boat, a skiff... ANGLE ON: RAMSAY, talking into a FIELD TELEPHONE, watchin from atop DOVER CASTLE.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL RAMSAY
dialogues.text: It will take time. It’s too soon to judge.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: How many boats so far?

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL RAMSAY
dialogues.text: It will take time.  68.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: The request for civilian boats was not a request, Bertie. It was an order! In frustration, WINSTON slams down the PHONE, as - - SAWYERS, the VALET, enters and draws the curtains. As L floods the room--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CROWD of ON-LOOKERS are gathered there, as - - WINSTON, emerges to get into a GOVERNMENT CAR. He is an ridden now, gives the (POLITE) V-FOR-VICTORY SIGN, (PALM- but his heart isn’t in it. Hunch-backed, his eyes downcas he gets in his GOVERNMENT CAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON and the KING at lunch at a DINING TABLE. WINSTON heartily. The KING, with little appetite, smokes, watches WINSTON wash down the food with hearty gulp of champagne.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: (pours drinks) How do you manage drinking during the day?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Practice. After another silence -

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: I have been asked--if plans should be drawn--to evacuate my f-family and I--to Canada. I wish to know the opinion of our prime minister.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: My opinion? My opinion would be that you must do what you feel is right for yourself, your family, and for the country. Your survival is paramount. Prime Ministers--we seem to come and go at an astonishing rate.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Your--p-position in parliament, I hear, is not strong.  69.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: My party resents how Chamberlain was pushed aside. And many others doubt me. I was not a popular choice. The KING nods - he himself resented WINSTON - and he turn away briefly, in embarrassment. WINSTON (CONT’D) They want Halifax still. But why get rid of the organ grinder and replace him with the monkey.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Lord Halifax is a close personal friend of mine!

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I am unwanted. I’ve never been trusted since the Gallipoli campaign. Unwanted.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Perhaps--it is because--you scare people.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Who?!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: You scare me.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (scarily) What?! What nonsense! What could be scary about me?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: One never knows what is going to come out of your mouth next. Something that w-will flatter-- or wound.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: My emotions are unbridled. WINSTON drops some meat into the mouth of a CORGIE waitin WINSTON’s feet for food. WINSTON (CONT’D) A wildness. In the blood. I share it with my father. (beat) Mother also. We lack the gift of-- temperance.  70.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Were you close--to your parents?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: My mother was glamorous--but perhaps too widely loved. This draws an eye-brow rise from the King. WINSTON (CONT’D) My father--to me was like God-- busy elsewhere. The KING smiles. He cannot help but like this man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON walks through the MEN and WOMEN en route to his O He stops before ELIZABETH LAYTON - looks into her eyes. S see the DOUBT, the SADNESS, the PAIN.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Miss Layton.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH LAYTON
dialogues.text: Sir.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Reach--I need to reach--speak to...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH LAYTON
dialogues.text: To?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: 3pm.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH LAYTON
dialogues.text: 3pm, sir?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Ask Bridges to summon the--the uh-- the War Cabinet for 3pm. Thank you. She watches him walk away - - only for WINSTON to be stopped by JOHN EVANS with a COMMUNIQUE.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN EVANS
dialogues.text: Sir!

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN EVANS
dialogues.text: Sir-from Lord Gort, in France.  71. WINSTON reads the message -- his EYES WIDEN.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Belgium has fallen. They will surrender at midnight. France will soon follow suit. REACTION WINSTON: Shock.

dialogues.speaker: WAR CABINET MEETING 3.
dialogues.text: PRESENT: 9 PERSONS. The Main War Cabinet (CHURCHILL, CHAMBERLAIN, HALIFAX, GREENWOOD, ATLEE) and the FOLLOWING (EDEN, CADOGAN, IRONSIDE, BRIDGES. )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FILM REEL is projected onto a SCREEN. We see images of GERMAN SPEEDBOATS. We see the NAZI leadership, holding ma pointing out to sea toward Britain...We see a giant LONG- RANGE SUPER CANNON being revealed by GERMAN soldiers. Ove this, we hear -

dialogues.speaker: IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: We have received reports that the most probable method of attack, which Germany might employ against this country, is a large fleet of fast motor boats, possibly up to 200, carrying 100 men apiece to carry out a seaborne raid on a large scale. By this means a considerable force of the enemy could be landed at many points on the coast simultaneously with air- borne raids inland. We do not feel that by naval or air action we could prevent such a landing.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: Could you repeat that? HALIFAX turns to look hard at WINSTON.

dialogues.speaker: IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: We must prepare for the imminent invasion of our island. The shock registers on all the faces. Hold on ANTHONY EDE he lowers his HEAD. BRIDGES opens a BOTTLE of WHISKEY and starts to pour into tumblers for the non-military personnel. Silence, as IRONSIDE sits.  72. Silence. Lost looks. General state of high anxiety. They to WINSTON for leadership - and he appears to be about to something in response to this black news - BUT NO WORDS C After this awkward silence - HALIFAX looks directly at WINSTON —

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: Let the record state--that I have received word from the Italian Embassy in London that Italy is prepared to mediate a resolution between Britain, its Allies, and Germany. The CABINET SECRETARY, records this statement for history WINSTON fumes that this has been put on the record and st with anger at HALIFAX. WINSTON has been totally put on the spot!

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (sunk by the news) Perhaps--then-- The CABINET waits on the final INEVITABLE words - WINSTON (CONT’D) --the time for such an offer from us is - HALIFAX nods at CHAMBERLAIN - success, surely! But WINSTO can’t speak the words they ache to hear. WINSTON (CONT’D) - is when Germany has made an unsuccessful attempt to invade this country. HALIFAX throws his GLASSES on the table in DISBELIEF!

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Unsuccessful?!

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: Then you leave me no other option -

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) Winston--you are refusing to grasp the realities of how precarious our position is! Our entire army is about to be wiped out! Terms! Must! Be struck! Silence. WINSTON has no room left in which to move. ALL F examine his.  73. WINSTON looks finally to ANTHONY EDEN - his staunchest supporter.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Anthony? EDEN’s face is pained - as he retains a MEANINGFUL SILENC CHURCHILL looks to each MAN around the room, and their fa proclaim their support of HALIFAX’s view. UTTERLY ISOLATED - WINSTON has no choice now. WINSTON (CONT’D) Then... (pause) Then it seems... (pause) ...we have no choice but to at least consider the path of negotiation. CHAMBERLAIN and HALIFAX share an astonished look! WINSTON (CONT’D) If Hitler’s peace terms are-- overlordship of Central Europe and return of certain German colonies - (pause) - and if he will leave us our independence, then - then I would be thankful to get out of our present difficulties. It’s quite unlikely that he will make any such offer, but... WINSTON looks at the CABINET SECRETARY who records for posterity his every word -— WINSTON (CONT’D) ...if I were told what the German terms were, then--I would be-- prepared---to--to consider them. The SECRETARY notes down this historic concession, and WINSTON observes this.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: Thank you. Prime Minister. CHAMBERLAIN nods at HALIFAX. They have prevailed.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (triumphant) I shall prepare a draft memorandum at once. Finally, WINSTON nods. CHAMBERLAIN and HALIFAX look at ea other again - victory!  74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIGH WIDE-SHOT as WINSTON walks through the TREASURY DRUM toward DOWNING STREET. MILES ALDRIDGE, a lone photographer calls out -

dialogues.speaker: MILES ALDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Mr. Churchill! One picture, one picture, come on sir, one picture! How about a smile, Prime Minister? WINSTON steps toward him, and then DELIBERATELY gives the RUDE VERSION of the V-FOR-VICTORY sign (PALM-INWARD). Win walks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHAMBERLAIN, alone, steadies himself against a wall - his health is fading. He takes out his bottle of MORPHINE and drinks.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. BUCKINGHAM PALACE
dialogues.text: KING GEORGE walks out on to a BALCONY and looks down the in BLACKOUT, as his EQUERRY joins him...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: I was--ju--just imagining never standing--here again. Perhaps because I am no longer alive, or-- or because the palace itself-- is gone.

dialogues.speaker: EQUERRY
dialogues.text: Canada. You must decide, sir. You could rule in exile.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Truly? Is that my fate? (pause) You know what? I feel angry. In this moment I’m aware of feeling-- bloody angry. The EQUERRY studies him, as he studies the MALL. INT. ELIZABETH'’S “SHOE-BOX” ROOM/ WAR ROOMS - NIGHT ELIZABETH LAYTON waits, her fingers at the ready. She sne a glance at the CLOCK on her DESK - it is 1.30! WINSTON is in a BLACK MOOD. He struggles to DICTATE a SPEECH...  75.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I have...come to...to wonder...in... recent days...whether it was...my duty... ECU of: the TYPEWRITER hammers typing “duty” - WINSTON (CONT’D) - to consider... EVANS enters, carrying a TRAY holding a glass and a bottl Elizabeth yawns. WINSTON (CONT’D) ...consider...entering... EVANS is standing there staring at WINSTON, waiting to kn off for the night. WINSTON notices -

dialogues.speaker: JOHN EVANS
dialogues.text: Will that be all for tonight, sir? WINSTON ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: -..entering into negotiations with... (unable to speak the dreaded name) .-.-that...corporal...no... EVANS departs without an answer, as - WINSTON pours himse SCOTCH and mumbles to himself - WINSTON (CONT’D) ---gangster--no--tyrant... ..-monster of wickedness, no... WINSTON, wanting more inspiration, turns over a NEWSPAPER on the COVER is - a LARGE PHOTO of ADOLPH HITLER. WINSTON looks at HITLER'S FACE with LOATHING - WINSTON (CONT’D) ..-butcher--no good--monstrous savage?--bloodthirsty guttersnipe!-- housepainter... (throws newspaper on the ground)

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEPAINTER
dialogues.text: (his head clears) Where were we? Where - ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON, hearing no sound of typing, turns - and sees ELIZABETH LAYTON staring at her TYPEWRITER, frozen - WINSTON (CONT’D) Well?  76.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (softly) I didn’t understand you, sir. He doesn’t reply. She finally adds -

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were —

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Were?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You were - mumbling.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Mumbling.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Yes sir. WINSTON, crosses to the other side of her and sits down - picks up a FRAMED PHOTO of A HANDSOME YOUNG SOLDIER from desk.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Your beau? ELIZABETH maintains her composure with true grit during t following exchange -

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: My brother.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Where is he now?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: He was falling back on Dunkirk but he never made it. This rocks WINSTON to the core. He studies ELIZABETH, sti by the beauty of her sad face.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? His eyes moisten - at all she represents, innocence and l and courage and purity.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I’m just looking at you. She turns back to her TYPE-WRITER and sits there waiting, until - feeling awkward - she offers -—

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Shall I read back what we have?  77.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: “I have come to wonder in recent days whether it was my duty to consider entering into negotiations-— -with...” WINSTON ponders his next line - but again, NO WORDS COME.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: With...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON emerges on to the ROOFTOP of the building, and proceeds to LIGHT UP a CIGAR as he takes in the CLEAR NIG SKY above him.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: -.-with... He then hears a DRONE... it is a SINGLE SPITFIRE on NIGHT PATROL. It comes into view, slowly crossing the sky. WINSTON watches this GHOSTLY SIGHT come and go. The littl plane looks very small in such a big expanse of sky... His eyes are WET with TEARS, as he ANGRILY GRINDS OUT his CIGAR. The CAMERA rises up - up - into an AERIAL SHOT of - - WINSTON on the ROOF until - WINSTON is no bigger than a LEAD SOLDIER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLEMMIE enters and sees - WINSTON, sitting on a large boa shaped bed in the dark staring into space, amid UNPACKED BOXES. He’s at a very low ebb.

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: Darling, Winston, Darling? No answer. She goes to him. He’s clearly in trouble -

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: Shhh. Shhh. You’ve the full weight of the world on your shoulders. But these inner battles, darling -  78.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I can’t -

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: - I know, I know - but they have actually trained you for this moment. You are strong because you are imperfect. You are wise because you have doubts. From this uncertainty the wisest words will come. Now. I will let him in.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: The King.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Which King? Our King?

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: Well if it isn’t him, it’s a wonderful impersonation. CLEMMIE closes the door. WINSTON looks DISHEVELLED, his s RUMPLED. A Mess. He makes a small effort to tuck in a shi and buttons his waistcoat. KING GEORGE VI enters - the most ‘proper’ man in Europe. height of manners and decorum. Wears an IMPECCABLE SUIT.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Mr Churchill--I hope you can for-- give the late hour but your wife thought tonight would be a good time. Winston is standing by the bed.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE VI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shall we sit? The KING sits in an ARMCHAIR. Winston sits on the bed. WINSTON makes a futile effort to put on his public face..

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Something to drink? Er -

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: No, thank you. WINSTON remains seated on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE VI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I received a visit...  79.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: From?

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Viscount Halifax. (beat) It appears--the prospect of a peace deal with Hitler--has increased dramatically.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Later today I will address The House. The war cabinet is drafting a letter to Mussolini, asking him to broker talks with Herr Hitler.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Then Halifax was correct.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I should like to know your mind.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: It would be helpful to know yours first.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Mine? I should like to know it myself. (beat) Nations which go down fighting rise again, but those which surrender tamely are finished.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Belgium?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Collapsed.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Norway -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Holland. France any hour. After a hard silence -

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: And the mood of parliament?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Fear. Panic.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: And are you not afraid? At all?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I am most terribly. scrutinizes him closely - WINSTON (CONT’D) Our defeat in France is the most crushing in the history of the Empire. Support among my party for a campaign of resistance has collapsed. Finally - GEORGE has heard what he has wanted to hear, an makes his pledge - He moves to sit next to Winston on the bed

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: You have my support. WINSTON cannot believe his ears. WINSTON —

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Your Majesty?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: You have my support. (pause) I must confess, I had some reservations about you at-at first. And while some in this country might have dreaded your appointment, none dreaded it like- like Adolph Hitler. speechless.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whomever can strike fear into that brute heart is worthy of all our trust. We shall work together. You shall have my support. At any hour. (passionate) Beat the buggers.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I fear I may be defeated.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: You--you once gave me some advice. Perhaps I can give you some. Go to the people. Let them instruct you. Quite silently, they usually do. But tell them the truth. Unvarnished.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I shall speak to parliament, but without support in my own party, I must sue for peace.  81.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: You warned us this day was coming. We failed to listen to you. Lift us up, Mr Churchill.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: On certain matters I have few people with whom I can talk frankly.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Perhaps now we have each other?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I no longer scare you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE VI
dialogues.text: Only a little. I can cope.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Yes you can. Your majesty. They remain sitting there, side by side on the boat-shape bed, friends hereafter.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTION
dialogues.text: RAMSAY, dressed in UNIFORM, is on the phone to - INT. WINSTON’S BEDROOM/ 10 DOWNING STREET - MORNING - WINSTON, in bed, taking the call. (INTERCUT, as necessary - )

dialogues.speaker: RAMSAY
dialogues.text: We are ready. More or less.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: More or less what, Bertie? Give me a number!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAMSAY opens the METAL FRENCH DOORS and steps out onto -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAMSAY’s POV OF: over 800 SMALL boats, the “LITTLE SHIPS" ARRIVING or MOORED. NAVAL officers and VOLUNTEERS board t A RAG-TAG ARMADA.  82.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSAY
dialogues.text: In total--860 vessels. The biggest civilian fleet ever assembled.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: May God watch over them all. The SHOT PULLS AWAY from RAMSAY on the BALCONY -

dialogues.speaker: RAMSAY
dialogues.text: Operation Dynamo waits upon your command... - and we reveal - that the BALCONY of his BEDROOM is cut right into the cliff-face of THE WHITE CLIFFS OF DOVER!

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Admiral--you may initiate Dynamo. - CAMERA pulls back and back - until we see the ENTIRE ENGLISH COASTLINE, complete with the “DYNAMO” FLEET. EXT/INT. PRINCES STREET/ WINSTON’S CAR - DAY WIDE SHOT of - WINSTON’s CAR, moving slowly through the r street. WINSTON, in the back seat, looks out the window a the human traffic - seems like he’s in a gold-fish bowl, disconnected. He watches as - MEN IN BOWLER HATS and YOUN WOMEN in SUMMER DRESSES walk to work. As they rush throug the rain shielding themselves with umbrellas and newspape WINSTON, with an UNLIT CIGAR in his mouth, searches his pockets for a MATCH. But he can’t find his matches. When the CAR stops at a RED LIGHT - - TOM LEONARD hears the car door slam. He turns, looks ba WINSTON has jumped out of his car. Tom Leonard opens his and stands looking around for Winston, as crowds rush pas the pouring rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIDGES puts down the TELEPHONE and turns to the ASSEMBLE WAR CABINET -—

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGES
dialogues.text: We've lost the Prime Minister!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CROWD of COMMUTERS parts to reveal - WINSTON, closely studying the UNDERGROUND MAP, trying to it out, until he is RECOGNISED for the FIRST TIME.  83. A great commotion starts, as people watch respectfully th PRIME MINISTER trying to work out how to use the TUBE. ANGLE ON: WINSTON, studying the MAP, lighting a CIGAR, as - a TEENAGE GIRL stands beside him. She looks at the MAP WINSTON notices her.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Do you know how to use this thing?

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GIRL
dialogues.text: Yes - (recognising him, her eyes widen) - yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: So--tell me--how do I get to Westminster?

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GIRL
dialogues.text: Westminster? Um, the District Line. East. One stop.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: District Line. East. One stop. Doesn’t sound so hard.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GIRL
dialogues.text: No, sir. WINSTON stalks off, taking the steps down, down. Now ever is stopping to let him go by - PEOPLE are STUNNED SPEECHL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON arrives on the PLATFORM as a TRAIN arrives. The b CHATTER dies down at once - as everyone recognizes WINSTO

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: So--this is the Underground! He BOARDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He boards the TRAIN with an UNLIT CIGAR in his mouth. COM look up and FALL SILENT at once, all RISING to their feet a Lady has entered a room. WINSTON tips his HAT to them.  84.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: What are you all staring at? Have you never seen a Prime Minister ride on the Underground before. When he sits, the COMMUTERS follow suit. The TRAIN doesn’t immediately start going. He waits. Then looks around him. EVERYBODY is doing their best to be well mannered and not but all are failing! They immediately avert their eyes fr WINSTON. WINSTON remembers his unlit CIGAR - WINSTON (CONT’D) Does anyone have a match? Down the CARRIAGE an OLD MAN shakes a box of matches. WIN rises and goes to him. The OLD MAN strikes a match on the THIRD STRIKE. With a SHAKING HAND he lights WINSTON’s CIG WINSTON (CONT’D) Thank you. WINSTON offers his hand... WINSTON (CONT’D) What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Oliver Wilson, sir.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: And what do you do Mr Wilson?

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Brick-layer, sir.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Good! (loudly) We shall have great need of brick- layers soon! Business will be looking up! The GROUP laughs, as - the TRAIN lurches into MOTION. WINSTON (CONT’D) Progress! The mood of REVERENCE lightens now, as WINSTON goes to - - a WOMAN WITH A BABY, touches its head. WINSTON (CONT’D) How old?  85.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN WITH BABY
dialogues.text: Eight months, sir. He looks like you.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Madam, all babies look like me. The causes widespread DELIGHT. Another woman steps up to shake his hand -

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN WITH BABY
dialogues.text: Mrs Jessie Sutton. Everyone has got the hang of this now, and don’t need to spoken to. They step forward in close order -

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: (shaking WINSTON'’s hand) Abigail Walker.

dialogues.speaker: WEST-INDIAN MAN
dialogues.text: (shaking WINSTON'’s hand) Marcus Peters.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG IRISH WOMAN
dialogues.text: (shaking WINSTON'’s hand) Agnes Dillon.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: (shaking WINSTON'’s hand) Maurice Baker.

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLE AGED WOMAN
dialogues.text: (shaking WINSTON'’s hand) Alice Simpson.

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN
dialogues.text: (shaking WINSTON'’s hand) Miss Margaret Jerome.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: My mother was a Jerome--I expect we are closely related! Laughter. He now switches into SPEECH MODE, switches on the inner l

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And how are you all bearing up? A great hearty response. WINSTON (CONT’D) Of good spirits? Just as well! (laughter) We will need them! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON (CONT’D) Now let me ask you all something-- which has been weighing on my mind. Perhaps you can provide me with an answer. A hushed SILENCE again - they wait. He studies their face reading their minute expressions - WINSTON (CONT’D) The British people. What is their mood? Is it confident?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Very.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Some people say it’s a lost cause.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Lost causes are the only ones worth fighting for. Now let me ask you this--if the worst came to pass, and the enemy were to appear on these streets, what would you do?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Fight.

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLE AGED WOMAN
dialogues.text: Fight the fascists!

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Fight them with whatever we can lay our hands on!

dialogues.speaker: IRISH WOMAN
dialogues.text: Broom handles if we must!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: Street by street!

dialogues.speaker: WEST-INDIAN MAN
dialogues.text: They'll never take Picadilly!

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Ha!Ha! Never Picadilly indeed! The public laugh. WINSTON SMILES, proud of these people -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And what--what if I put it to you all--that we might - if we ask hicely - receive very favourable terms from Mr. Hitler if we enter into a peace deal with him right now? What would you say to that?  87.

dialogues.speaker: NEVER
dialogues.text: A pause, and then -

dialogues.speaker: NEVER
dialogues.text: When SILENCE returns, one (young) voice chimes in, late -

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GIRL
dialogues.text: Never! WINSTON turns to look for the source of the voice and he sees, and moves toward, one YOUNG GIRL...

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Will you never give up?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GIRL
dialogues.text: Never. Touched, he crosses and sits down opposite the child -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: (to YOUNG GIRL) “Then out spake brave Horatius, The Captain of the gate: To every man upon this earth Death cometh soon or late. And how can man die better Than facing fearful odds - “

dialogues.speaker: WEST INDIAN MAN
dialogues.text: “—- for the ashes of his fathers And the temples of his gods.” Everyone is moved. WINSTON, himself, has tears in his eye He wipes his eyes with a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GIRL
dialogues.text: Are you crying?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I blub a lot. You’1l have to get used to it. The TRAIN stops. WINSTON (CONT’D) What stop is this?

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLE AGED WOMAN
dialogues.text: Westminster.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: That’s my stop.  88. Before stepping off the TRAIN he stops to look into the f of the good, brave, true people. Emboldened by their simp courage, he exits.

dialogues.speaker: WAR CABINET MEETING 4.
dialogues.text: PRESENT: 17 PERSONS. The Main War Cabinet, minus WINSTON (WINSTON’s CHAIR remains empty): (CHAMBERLAIN, HALIFAX, GREENWOOD, ATLEE) and the FOLLOWING (EDEN, ALEXANDER,

dialogues.speaker: IRONSIDE, BRIDGES, ISMAY, NICHOLL, WILKINSON.
dialogues.text: All are actively discussing the wording of a PEACE OFFER. HALIFAX, leading the formulation of the offer, looks very pleased with the current situation.

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: The Memorandum--titled “Suggested Approaches to Italy”--is as follows...

dialogues.speaker: CADOGAN
dialogues.text: “Tf Signor Mussolini will co- operate with us in securing a settlement of all European questions which safeguard the independence and security of the allies...” CAMERA moves in on: WINSTON’s SILVER BOX OF MATCHES.

dialogues.speaker: EXT HOUSE OF COMMONS
dialogues.text: WINSTON comes up from WESTMINSTER TUBE STATION and crosse PARLIAMENT.

dialogues.speaker: CADOGAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: “,..and could be the basis of a just and durable peace for Europe, we will undertake at once to discuss, with the desire to find solutions, the matters in which Signor Mussolini is primarily interested...”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deep in anxious thought, WINSTON stalks in to the House o Commons and walks down a long hallway....  89.

dialogues.speaker: CADOGAN
dialogues.text: .."We understand that he desires the solution of certain Mediterranean questions: and if he will state in secrecy what these are, France and Great Britain will at once do their best to meet those wishes”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the first floor and is met by a relieved JOHN EVANS -

dialogues.speaker: JOHN EVANS
dialogues.text: Sir! The War Cabinet is waiting!

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I am due to address the Outer Cabinet. I haven’t spoken to them since the formation of the new government. Moving up the HALLWAY, WINSTON and EVANS pass huddled gro of YOUNGER MP’s - WINSTON STOPS, thinks, and then turns back to them. WINSTON (CONT’D) Good day. (pause) I am--about to speak to my Outer Cabinet in my rooms and--I extend the invitation to any of you who would care to join them. WINSTON forces a SMILE, then departs. After a moment, the MP’s rise, look at each other, murmur rise and follow him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ROOM is now FULL with 40 MEN - CABINET MEMBERS and YO BACK-BENCHERS. WINSTON enters, with JOHN EVANS - shakes the hand of YOUN CONSERVATIVE MP (ERNLE HASTINGS) . The DOORS are CLOSED. WINSTON stands in front of the GATHERING. They wait for him to speak. At first no words come from WINSTON, and then -  90.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Later today--I will address the House on the matter of our nation’s security. (silence) At this very moment the War Cabinet is drafting papers that lay out our willingness to enter into peace talks with Herr Hitler, via his lacky, Signor Mussolini. (pause) I have thought carefully in these last days--whether - (pause) -whether it was part of my duty-- to consider entering into negotiations with - (beat) - that Man. He puts on his GLASSES and takes out a MATCH-BOOK - on wh is written the names of the people he met in the Undergro WINSTON (CONT’D) But then I spoke--with Oliver Wilson - (starts to read names from his matchbook) - Mrs Jessie Sutton, Mrs Abigail Walker... ANGLE ON: the CARD. The names of the TUBE COMMUTERS are a written there... REACTION: MP’s, slight confusion as they try to remember these people are... WINSTON (CONT’D) ...-Marcus Peters, Agnes Dillon, Maurice Baker, Alice Simpson, and Miss Margaret Jerome--brave, good, true citizens of this kingdom--and they argued, strongly, that it was idle to think that, if we tried to make peace now, we should get better terms than if we fought it out. The Germans, Mr Baker felt, would demand - in the name of disarmament - our naval bases, and much else. And I think he’s right. Jessie Sutton, speaking for many, believes we should then become a slave state, though a British Government - which would be Hitler's puppet - would be set up - under Mosley or some such person.  91.

dialogues.speaker: ERNLE HASTINGS
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: And I join with them in asking a further question, a question I put to you: where should we be at the end of all that? He SURVEYS their silent UNCERTAIN FACES. WINSTON (CONT’D) (silence) Perhaps some might benefit--the powerful might be able to parlay good terms--preserved in their country redoubts, out of sight of the Swastika flying on Buckingham Palace, over Windsor, draped on these very buildings -

dialogues.speaker: BACK-BENCHER 1
dialogues.text: Never!

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: So I come to you--to learn your minds in this grave hour. The FACES of the MP’s are RESOLUTE, MOVED, READY TO FIGHT WINSTON (CONT’D) You see, we do still have immense reserves and advantages... A NOISE begins to build in the room, mumbling, turning in shouts, over which WINSTON must shout - WINSTON (CONT’D) -..and it was pointed out to me - (holding up list of names from Underground) - by my new friends--that you might even rise up and tear me down were I for one moment to contemplate parley or surrender. A spontaneous round of emotional applause. It surprises WINSTON. It surprises even those who are applauding. WINSTON (CONT’D) Were they wrong?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Then...then...then -  92. The DIN dies down. When silence returns... WINSTON (CONT’D) - then--it appears to be your will also, that if this long island story of ours is to end at last, then it should only be - (pause, then powerfully -) - when each one of us lies choking in his own blood upon the ground! A GIANT HOORAY goes up and the YOUNG MPs RUSH UP to WINST who is soon SWAMPED by MPs shaking his HAND, PATTING HIM the back - a MASSIVE SIGN OF SUPPORT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON somberly addresses the WAR CABINET (plus ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: And when I asked to know their minds there occurred a demonstration which, considering the character of the gathering, quite surprised me. There is no doubt that if we falter at all in the leading of the nation we should all be hurled out of office. I am sure now that every Minister on both sides of the house is ready to be killed quite soon, and have all his family and possessions destroyed, rather than give in. In this they represent almost all the people. It falls to me in these coming days and months to express their sentiments. There shall be no negotiated peace... (to HALIFAX) --and you must each do now as you see fit. (beat) I must now address parliament, and I’m yet to write a word of my speech. WINSTON grabs his SILVER BOX OF MATCHES left earlier on t table - WINSTON (CONT’D) There’s the buggers. - then walks out, passing the tall IRONSIDE, and clapping the shoulder. WINSTON (CONT’D) “Tiny”.  93. GENERAL IRONSIDE - having his war at last - smiles.

dialogues.speaker: IRONSIDE
dialogues.text: Sir. EDEN happily follows his LEADER now. REACTION: HALIFAX. BETRAYAL. CHAMBERLAIN avoids HALIFAX’s eyes. ATTLEE and GREENWOOD smile. INT. CORRIDOR - WAR ROOMS / ELIZABETH’S ROOM - DAY WINSTON walks toward ELIZABETH LAYTON’s “Shoe-Box” room, knocks, opens the door, remains in the doorway -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Miss Layton? ELIZABETH looks up from her work -

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: I’m in need of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HALIFAX detains CHAMBERLAIN as the CABINET leaves the mee

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: We must both now resign. Force a vote of no confidence. I have your word?

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Let us--let us go to the Commons first. Join our colleagues. And speak after the Prime Minister's address. CHAMBERLAIN takes his coat and leaves HALIFAX worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLEMMIE is getting dressed, and then turns to look at her in the mirror, and reveal - - that she is in UNIFORM (Red Cross).

dialogues.speaker: CLEMMIE
dialogues.text: (to her reflection) Here lies a woman, who is always tired--for she lived in a world where too much was required.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA moves in on WINSTON’S PARKED CAR, and we gradually hear the sound of - TYPING. Through the WINDOW of the CAR we finally see - WINSTON, dictating to ELIZABETH LAYTON, her TYPE-WRITER o her knee going clack, clack, clack. (WINSTON gesticulates he composes the crucial words.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINSTON addresses a PACKED HOUSE of COMMONS. A CROWD of s FIVE HUNDRED listen, with more in the GALLERY. Among the GALLERY crowd, JOHN EVANS. ELIZABETH LAYTON arrives late, and learns over the hand-r looking down anxiously at - WINSTON, as he launches his final assault -

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Turning once again--to the question of invasion--I would observe that there has never been a period in all these long centuries of which we boast, when an absolute guarantee against invasion could have been given to our people. ANGLE ON: HALIFAX, in the GALLERY, keenly watching. WINSTON (CONT’D) I have, myself--full confidence that if all do their duty, if nothing is neglected, and if the best arrangements are made, as they are being made, we shall prove ourselves once more able to defend our island home, to ride out the storm of war, and to outlive the menace of tyranny -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLEMMIE, in her UNIFORM, listens to WINSTON’s broadcast o the RADIO, as she has her portrait photographed by CECIL BEATON. She is awkward in front of the camera.  95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The KING smokes as he listens to the same broadcast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: which she

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: - if necessary for years, if necessary alone. At any rate, that is what we are going to try to do. That is the resolve of His Majesty's Government - every man of them. That is the will of Parliament and the nation. The British Empire and the French Republic, linked together in their cause and in their need, will defend to the death their native soil, aiding each other like good comrades to the utmost of their strength. ELIZABETH, who is “mouthing” these words, some of already knows by heart - WINSTON (CONT’D) Even though large tracts of Europe and many old and famous States have fallen or may fall into the grip of the Gestapo and all the odious apparatus of Nazi rule, we shall not flag or fail. We shall go on to the end. We shall fight in France--we shall fight on the seas and oceans, we shall fight with growing confidence and growing strength in the air, we shall defend our island - whatever the cost may be. We shall fight on the beaches, we shall fight on the landing grounds, we shall fight in the fields and in the streets, we shall fight in the hills; We shall never surrender, and if, which I do not for a moment believe, this island or a large part of it were subjugated and starving, then our Empire beyond the seas, armed and guarded by the British Fleet, would carry on the struggle, until, in God's good time, the New World, with all its power and might, steps forth to the rescue and the liberation of the old!  96. The LABOUR BENCHES begin to wave their papers in the air call their approval, (it is against Parliamentary etiquet to ever clap in the House of Commons). WINSTON’S children bang their hands on the woodwork. WINSTON’s CONSERVATIVE colleagues all look to CHAMBERLAIN CLOSE ON: HALIFAX, looking down from the GALLERY at CHAMBERLAIN, closes his eyes, knowing what is coming next - CHAMBERLAIN TAKES OUT HIS WHITE HANDKERCHIEF, and tamps his forehead with it. It’s enough. The CONSERVATIVE FACTION, ignited, rises to their feet in THUNDEROUS SUPPO of WINSTON. REACTION HALIFAX: Defeat. WINSTON turns to ANTHONY EDEN, registering surprise at th strength of support, and winks - EDEN grins and SHAKES his FRIEND’s HAND.

dialogues.speaker: EDEN
dialogues.text: Changed your mind?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON
dialogues.text: Those who never change their mind never change anything. The UPROAR in the HOUSE continues, those in the gallery b to throw their parliamentary papers into the air which th rain down into the chamber.

dialogues.speaker: STANHOPE
dialogues.text: What just happened?

dialogues.speaker: HALIFAX
dialogues.text: He just mobilized the English language--and sent it into battle. Every man is on his feet waving their parliamentary paper and throwing them into the air, shouting and stamping. Smiling with due deference WINSTON takes up his things an walks down the central aisle of the house as papers conti to rain down from the gallery like ticker tape or confett As the GREAT DOORS of the COMMONS close behind him - the screen becomes BLACK. Up with END CAPTIONS:  97.

dialogues.speaker: VOTED OUT OF OFFICE BY THE BRITISH PEOPLE.
dialogues.text: “SUCCESS IS NOT FINAL, FAILURE IS NOT FATAL: IT IS THE

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Roll End Credits.
